I will say that I think that small plates are overdone and used to generate higher profits at the expense of empty stomachs. And many tapas places, with the recommended 2 - 3 plate/customer at $10-$15/plate, have done well by that model. I for one have gone home hungry too many times to have been taken again. However, Terzo breaks the mold and represents how it can work. 

The formula starts with a chef like Mark Gordon who has obviously made a deal with the devil because his pan-Mediterranean cuisine is unbelievably good. Another nice addition is the impeccable choice of local, seasonal ingredients and a menu that changes often. 

We had a small late dinner starting with the Steamed Mussels with oloroso sherry, bay leaf and grilled toasts. The broth from this will have you asking for a straw or more bread.  
Side by side we had the perfectly Roasted Beets with yogurt, garlic and dill. If you like beets, these are deliciously flavorful and perfectly cooked. 
Next up was the Chicken Spiedini (a kabab) with bread, chile and onions. Succulent, flavorful, these chicks were raised right and tasted so.  
Along with our meal we ended up going through three glasses of the 2003 Quinta de Cabriz Reserva from Portugal which was a great match for the food. Not overpowering and yet enough body and spice to stand up to the rich and flavorful food. 
We finished with milk and cookies and a cappuccino.  A perfect light meal that was a treat for the senses.
author: Phil M.

description:
I'd actually give this place 3.5 stars if I could. We came on a bad night - the bartender told my friend that they were short two wait staff. So we were seated at 9, despite our 8:30 reservation. The place is CROWDED! We awaited our table with a glass of sancerre as we attempted to stay out of the way by standing toward the front, right by the window. A really nice couple next to us offered us a seat, but we declined. 

So we were finally seated and got a bottle of savignon blanc (the birthday girl wanted white). Our waitress was very apologetic - and nice and competent. The hummus, prosciutto wrapped figs, and beef were delicious. I thought the halibut was just so-so, though my dining companions loved it. My favorite was the sausage - nice and spicy. After dinner we had a glass of rose as we decided what to have for dessert. We decided to split the Midnight Cake and it was fantastic. And I got a glass of Cockburn 20 year old Tawny Port, which was also fantastic (and fun to say!)

The wait staff was exceptionally nice. My friend informed the busboy that somebody had thrown up in the sink in the women's room (come on, what the fuck is wrong with you that you throw up in the SINK??). He came back up to thank her for letting him know and started joking around with us after I told him that she was actually the sink puker (she wasn't). And our waitress encouraged my 12 year old boy behavior as I repeated my order for the Cockburn over and over again!
author: Suge K.

description:
I was flipping through this month's Best of the Bay issue of SF Magazine and a feature on Terzo caught my eye. "A sleek venue where small plates offer great rewards" it said. Sounded fab, so I told fellow Yelper Yan M. about it and she checked Opentable.com for reservations and luckily there was 1 time slot that we could make. We were amazed that they were nearly booked on a Tuesday night. Once inside the restaurant we realized why - there are only about 10 tables, otherwise you can walk in and sit at the bar or their communal table which sits about 8 people. So it's a good idea to make reservations!

I was there with my lovely friends Yan and Helen Y. and being the Yelpers that we are, we paid attention to everything. Though we had reservations, we didn't get seated until about 30 minutes later. The hostess constantly apologized, and I think that because we were catching up and checking out all the dishes that were going by us, the time seemed to pass faster. It actually was helpful, because we would see dishes that we thought looked good, then we'd ask the server what it was and got their opinion about it. 

The menu only consists of 16 small plates, and our server recommended that we order at least 6 to share between the 3 of us. She gave us great suggestions and everything we got was delicious. I'm pretty sure you can't go wrong with any 16 of their dishes. My favorites were the hummus, chicken spiedini, and pancetta wrapped figs. We also got 2 desserts - warm berry crumble with ice cream and strawberries and ice cream on pavlova, this crisp and fluffy meringue dessert. Both perfect choices to end our wonderful meal with. 

Terzo is definitely going on my Best of the Bay list!
author: Connie C.

description:
I had a fantastic meal last night at Terzo...from the moment we walked in the door everything was spot on-the space is really comfortable and our server was right there with suggestions when needed.  Standouts were the hummus with some of the best homemade pita bread I've ever had, fava beans with marinated feta and flatbread and ravioli with peas.  The only miss of the night were the onion rings...they were actually pretty tasty but they definitely didn't go with the rest of the menu.
And leave room for dessert-the almond cake with strawberries, balsamic and creme was to die for!  Grand total for 6 small plates plus dessert and 4 glasses of wine was under $100.  
I'd highly recommend Terzo for a date spot although get there soon...our waiter mentioned that there's going to be a good write up in the Chronicle this weekend.  
Once that happens, good luck getting a table!
author: phil h.

description:
How can I describe this place while giving it the credit it deserves...

When visiting a classy, professionally maintained, no-nonsense, and well established restaurant, I expect a 
friendly greater (check), 
prompt seating if reservation (check), 
if early for res. bar waiting area (check), 
purse hooks under the bar (check). 
Possibly a warm fire (check)
Large fresh flower arrangement in the center of the room (check)
And flowing champagne (check)

My expectations were exceeded by the phenomenal service and warm ambiance. The food was delicious and Tapas style can be utterly satisfying when you order the desired amount.

I would recommend going in with a small group or a couple, the restaurant is very intimate, warm, and cozy. Not too loud, but the right place to start off for a great night.
author: Dee C.

description: Great food, you get what you pay for (which is high end), but go with at least 2 if not 4 people and share a few of the tasty small dishes: you will be happy.
author: Mike G.

description:
We came upon Terzo after a friend highly recommended the renovated spot.  I was hesitant because frankly, I am over the small plate scheme. Too little food for too high of a price. However, our friends raved about the quality of the food, and so we went. 

We have now been to Terzo several times and it really has become one of our favorite spots in the neighborhood for a lite dinner. The staff is extremely friendly, the wine offerings are great, and the food is absolutely delicious.  The only reason I withhold the fifth star is because the menu doesn't offer enough "hearty" dishes to sustain a return customer.  I usually like to select two meat/fish dishes, as well as a couple of vegetable sides and one of the salads. Terzo has plenty of vegetable varieties to choose from (all of which are extremely fresh and PERFECTLY prepared), but there is only about 4 items to choose from for the more "heartier" fare, and I would like to see about 4 more to choose from. It's just a bit too limited.

Other than that, I give Terzo 2 thumbs up and a genuine recommendation.

UPDATE (06/08/08):

Terzo is my favorite restaurant in the Cow Hollow area. Hands down it is delicious and the service is fantastic. We are regulars here and I love their changing seasonal menu. The food seems to have just gotten better and really deserves 5 stars
author: Anna S.

description: Had such a fun Friday night here! It was packed, but we were lucky to grab a table. The waiter knew the menu well and made excellent recommendations. Wine was delicious an well priced. We split three small plates and they were also amazing and filling! I was pleasantly surprised by how awesome the butternut squash was. I think it's the salt with the sweet favors. Unreal! I'd go back again and again.
author: Katie M.

description:
Went here last night with two friends, and had to say I was very pleased with the meal from start to finish.  

When they tell you that you should get 2-3 plats per person, that really is just about perfect.  Between the three of us, we got 7 plates, and it was really just the perfect amount of food.  We ordered: pacetta wrapped figs, roasted beets, heirloom tomato bruschetta, roasted chanterelle mushrooms, chicken spiedini, sausage, and the roasted beef.  Everything was really really good, with the sausage, figs and bruschetta being the standouts.

The wine list is great because it is loaded with non-Californian wines, and most of them are moderately prices (under $60).

The wait staff did a great job.  They were great about bringing the food out in groups of 2-3, so at no point were we sitting there with an empty table, but we also didn't have to deal with 7 plates on the table all at once.

All around, very satisfying meal -- I'll definitely be coming back!
author: Maneesh B.

description:
Not knowing anything of the place, but putting my trust in my good friend and food connoisseur Ray, I agreed to dinner at Terzo. (Plus, Ray was buying, so at the very least I knew I'd get some decent wine out of it). Turns out it's this trendy Mediterranean joint where the small plates are delicious and plentiful, the wine flows like beer, and beautiful women instinctively flock like the Cougars to the Triangle.

I'm an opportunistic wino, so for me the decor is comforting (you feel like you're in a wine cellar). And the food is fantastic, albeit slightly confusing at times (why is there a fried egg on my bruschetta? I have no idea, but it is tasty!). I recommend the aforementioned bruschetta-o-befuddlement, and their hummus which is splendid and served with home-made pita bread. 

Fellas, its a great place to take a strumpet. And ladies, your date will appreciate the fact that instead of hitting on you, the waiter will treat you like his sister (one who he beats up. Seriously, my waiter was super nice, but I'm unclear why he felt it necessary to forcefully pat me on the back everytime he walked by...)
author: Anna K.

description:
I only gave this place 3 stars for value. It's technically 4 for meals, location and atmosphere.   But the tapas plates are SMALL. Don't go thinking you will get a deal. They tell you to order 2-4 plates per person and we were still hungry. 

Who makes a pasta dish with 3 tortellini? I was with 4 people ( 2 guys and 2 women and we had to split up everything. And the Fava beans, goat cheese dish was excellent, but $7 for 3 slices of toast. Please. 

The gnocci was excellent as well as the artichoke ravioli's.  The waitstaff was nice, not amazing, and they forgot our mussels. My roommate went and said they had a great Pinot Noir. Go when you are not hungry!  Location is perfect!
author: Robin S.

description:
So, I went here the other night, without a reservation, but I still  really enjoyed the food. 
Once we got a seat, after standing around the very crowded bar, our server was very prompt and offered all kinds of suggestion's. We sat at the big family dinning table and that was a bit awkward, as all the other people who did not have a reservation are standing there wondering when you are going to leave? I did not really mind too much, and as soon as the wine came, I completely forgot about them.
We tried several dishes and yes, they are a bit small. I really enjoyed the baked cheese and the fillet of beef dish. We also splurged and had the apple tart, it was very tasty. The wine list looks like it would have something for everyone.
My only suggestion is to  GET  A RESERVATION!!
author: Lisa A.

description:
Really loved this place: ambiance/decor- clean, modern yet warm. loved the lighting, the wood, and the high table in the center where various groups of people are seated together. The bar setup is nice as well- easy to stand/sit and order drinks until you are seated. and random note-very cool flooring in the bathroom (bathroom was immaculate, spacious and modern-- ok, so the only reason I am so familiar with this particular room is that I had to change clothes in there (don't ask- it's nunya ).

Our waiter, Ron, was awesome- so good, that the tables to the left and right of me kept saying how highly they thought of him everytime he would walk away from the table.  

I just stuck to the small plates (my two person table ordered 5 small plates and it was perfect). I love the diversity in the dishes and the fact that the menu changes daily--it's a great mix of italian, greek and californian cuisine.  Definitely order the hummus and pita-- best pita (made fresh there) I've ever had..and amazing hummus. The roasted beets, cod in parchment paper,  chicory salad, and homemade sausage dishes were all so different (yet complementary) in flavor and texture, it was wonderful to sample so many flavorful dishes. 

The chocolate pudding cake was phenomenal -especially paired with their homemade coffee ice cream. 

definitely recommend this as a date place.
author: Sonia S.

description: Had a room in the back reserved for a party of 12 women.  We ordered a little bit of everything on the menu to share.  Everything was delicious.  There was not even one thing that we did not like, in fact there was tons of moaning in delight happening ;-)  .  Dessert and wine were also great.  Our service was amazing, especially for a party of 12.  We left feeling quite spoiled and well take care of.  I will be returning for more, probably quite a bit!
author: Amber L.

description:
This place is, like, ssoooo awesome!!!  Kevin (cutie pie) was ssoooo kewl.  So, like, we sit down and, like, he tells us to, like, order, like four (looks at Joe) or maybe five things.  ( I, like, giggle)
OH MY GOD....!  The summer squash carpaccio is ssooo, like, deelish.  And the Halibut with garbanzo beans...YUMMY.  And, like, for dessert...have the dark chocolate cake...OH MY GOD...I could, like, die now.
Minus one star because the apps. came out before the wine.  But Kevin is ssooo kewt and kewl, he looks and charm make up for it.
author: Gemma P.

description: My favorite neighborhood spot for dinner. Always great service and friendly staff. The food is consistently delicious. Nice ambience. Can't go wrong with dinner at Terzo!
author: Adrienne P.

description:
When in SF I usually end up in the typical business dinner place. I was looking for more of a unique neighborhood place and a friend sent me here. It was great. Nice ambiance, very accommodating hostess and servers and a creative menu. 

The apps and salads were all delicious. The entree's were creative but of varying quality. The pork chops were perfect, plump, juicy and nicely grilled on the outside. The salmon in fig leaf was very mild and a bit under seasoned. The The menu is heavy on the meat choices so its not very vegetarian friendly. 

The wine list had some very unique choices. We went for the rarely seen in restaurants Bianco Secco.
author: Adam M.

description:
It's hard for me to write this and give Terzo only three stars.  I've been going there for over four years (~100 great meals).  It's a beautiful restaurant with great service and exceptional food.  But, I'm finished with the place.  For some reason Terzo believes that all their patrons enjoy their raucous, annoying, disco-style music.  I don't!  I became" fed up" in September when I asked them four times to please "turn it down."  It didn't happen.

After a three month boycott, I sheepishly returned this month, believing that I had overreacted.  I hadn't!  The same obnoxious noise ruined my meal.  I may not fit their demographic being a youngish senior citizen, but I was a loyal customer who sadly will no longer patronize Terzo.

If you enjoy blaring music, this is the place for you because it is otherwise a gem.

I'm just glad I live in SF.  It it were Kansas, I'd probably have few alternatives - off to Cotogna!
author: John S.

description:
A little Stuffy.

I have been to Terzo numerous times, but after my second to last experience, I felt the need to, and finally got around to, writing a review. Possibly a scathing one, but not as to the food, only as to the service.

Most of my earlier experiences were good to quite good! The small shared portions are usually tasty, BUT, BE WARNED, the waiter/waitress will try to get you to over order. These dishes are more filling then they let on. Thus, I don't recommend you taking their recommendation on the size of your order. Otherwise, the wine and beer selection is commendable.

I went there with a large group for my cousin's birthday party and had a great experience, although my beloved, but very hard to please uncle (as he has several fancy restaurants of his own), was far from impressed.  When he was asked if he enjoyed the food and/or wine, the waiter got nothing but a smirk - as if to say, hmmm, so so, I've had much better. However, it is my opinion that he is used to food and wine that is far above par to that most to us are used to, even in San Francisco.

HOWEVER, AND MOST IMPORTANTLY, I had a lame duck experience when I took a group of nine people here for my girlfriend's 30th. I got there early to bring two cakes (from Tartine - which were amazing) and several bottles of wine. The hostess was nice, but the manager was very stuffy and difficult - lets say kind of a tart. It seemed like she couldn't even be genuinely nice if she tried, i.e., she basically ruined my experience. They have a corkage fee and a two bottle limit, however, this manager did let me bring three instead of two. Having said that, the hostess only charged me for two by mistake, when I came in early, because I wanted to pay beforehand. But, as I was leaving, the manager told me, rudely, that I had only paid for two, implying that I was a cheap skate and trying to get out of paying for the third. Truthfully, I hadn't even looked at the amount, and just figured they were able to figure it out correctly on their own. [for the record, Park Tavern credits you for corkage with each bottle of wine ordered from the rest - very cool.]  I was just trying to keep the cost down for the group. Nothing is worse than being invited to a birthday party, especially an obligatory one, and being compelled to fork over a bunch of money because folks want to be fancy. Expensive food should be agreed upon by all.

When I returned prior to dinner to set up the table with (admittedly crap I bought from party city [an utterly horrible place]) decorations and a balloon, this manager looked at me with horror as if I was some kind of trash.  Geesh, gist trying to make my girlfriend feel special. She was especially horrified by the large mylar happy 30th balloon and asked me where I was going to put it. I was going to ask her to help me decorate the table, her job, but I thought better of enlisting an ice queen to perform what was supposed to be a happy task for a happy occasion.  Luckily some of the female guests arrived shortly thereafter and helped me out. Thanks ladies!

The waiter was nice, but again a little annoyed that we didn't order right away. We were celebrating and drinking cocktails. He was also a little disappointed that we didn't order more, but as a stated above, they try to get you to over order - and did I mention I had two cakes.  Oh yea, they charge you five bucks a place to cut a piece of cake and put it on a plate. The only consolation is that there is a small serving of some sort of tasty cream. The waiter then seemed annoyed that his automatic tip (large group) wasn't going to be as high as he wished because of the wine we brought and the fact that we didn't feel like over ordering. However, he was happily surprised when he was way over tipped because everyone everyone overpaid and no one wanted any money back. (hell of a group - right!) This changed his tune and he smiled and patted me on the back on the way out. I would like to make it clear that overall, he was a good and attentive waiter, nothing like the ice queen of a manager.

Well, to end my long winded diatribe, which was my attempt at venting, the event turned out well. It was a surprise party, and the birthday girl was surprised. The table looked great, no thanks to the manager, and everyone had a good time! I'm pretty sure that I was the only one that was really miffed by the whole experience as I'm the only one that had any real interaction with this young "lady" of a manger. By the way, I thought that folks in the hospitality business were supposed to be, per se, nice, like really nice - especially when your bringing a group of nine to their establishment. However, the group was none to happy when I relayed the store after during drinks. 

Nuff said. The moral of this story is to try this place out, the food and booze are actually pretty darn good, just be careful not to be forced to over order and beware of the ice queen, well, ice princes. Ha ha ran out of chara
author: Will R.

description: I felt sophisticated and cool just being there - nice decor.  The grilled halibut and pancetta wrapped figs were ok.  Really liked the tender chicken kabobs, tasty eggplant, and crispy, delicate onion rings.  It seemed like there was cilantro or some green herbs on most of the dishes we ordered. Friendly & helpful wait staff.  More 3.5 for me and I'd definitely go there again.
author: Peg S.

description:
Tapas is just another word for rip-off. The small portions and hefty prices add up to you leaving hungry. 

The plates seemed uninspired to me. Arugula salad lacked flavor. Asparagus just didn't sing the way it should. Halibut with garbanzo beans was ho-hum. The bread/naan with the hummus was delicious. 

I do love the design and atmosphere. Maybe this place is better for a glass of wine than an anemic meal. They also have a communal table which is a cool concept.
author: Fog City T.

description:
I rarely give a restaurant a rave review but this place surprised me in the spectacular flavor and variety of dishes. I went twice in a week and both times were excellent. I admittedly dislike tapas places as i always leave feeling as if i ate too much rich food. I felt that Terzo had a nice blend of simple dishes, clean/fresh vegetable choices and richer meat and seafood options. Although the food tasted complex, the ingredients spoke for themselves and the it did not feel like it was trying too hard. I would recommend everything as i have tried everything on the menu, however it did seem to change quite a bit from one evening to the next!

I really like the ambiance, the music BUT as a party of two seated at the table it was hard to hear over the couples to either side of us. On my first visit I sat at the bar and it was far more preferable in terms of noise control! The service was great.

I was very surprised...don't go without a rezzie unless you are early.
author: pamela h.

description: This is one my husband's favorite spots.  Hands down the best meatballs in SF.  We always order so many small plates that we never make it to the mains.  Not cheap, but well worth it.
author: Jillian M.

description: Terzo is probably my favorite restaurant in the city. I've been here twice and will probably keep coming back. The food is delicious, beautifully fused and well prepared. I enjoy the nice modern interior, classy but not stuffy.
author: Phuc N.

description: Went here for a girls night bday dinner. We ordered a few small plates and they were delicious, the meatballs with polenta was my favorite and we ended up adding a second order of the chicekn spiedini. Great selection of wine and the chocolate flour-less cake was fantastic, we also ordered the strawberry shortcake, which was good, but the chocolate was by far the winner. Great spot.
author: KC H.

description:
I went to Terzo based on recommendations from other Yelpers.  There is definitely a good vibe in the restaurant and for a Monday night the restaurant was hopping.  Plates are very small for a party of 3 men and I would say that it is really just 3 bites worth of food.  Expect to pay the same amount as you would pay for a night out eating sushi.

Food quality were well prepared and is the gourmet version of your typical more gritty tapas dishes.  Unfortunately, no dish really wowed me so we leave it a 3 stars for now.  The kitchen I thought was a little slow but good for those who like to eat slow and drink wine.
author: Laurence H.

description: I just love Terzo. They have an excellent selection of wine, a sweet ambiance and nice servers! I tried the almond squash soup and I wanted 3 more bowls!
author: Katrina H.

description:
My Terzo experience was near perfect. Got a reservation on opentable, was seated right away (requested a seat in the front, so the tables are a little further away from eachother than in the back of the restaurant -- I prefer a bit of space and bar-style tables), and the service was friendly and very helpful. The wine by the glass list was extensive and both glasses I had were delicious. The food was tasty and the delivery was well timed-- can't speak for the meat dishes but the hummus, flat bread and carrot salad have me wishing I was going to eat there tonight. Get the carrots and the flatbread together -- perfect. 

And, they have Italian sodas on the menu! I love it when a restaurant has good non-alcoholic drink offerings.
author: Megan S.

description:
Okay, Terzo, let's set the record straight, right here, right now.  I'm desperately in love with you and it's for the following reasons:

1) Valet parking = Awesomely convenient [especially factoring in how difficult it can be to secure a street spot in the Marina/Cow Hollow 'hood.]

2) Accepting a semi-last minute reservation request for what some might consider "late" on a Friday night for 6 beautifully dressed girls [coming straight from the Opera, I might add]  ;-)

3) Funny-and-friendly-as-hell waitstaff.  [Ahem, Willoughby, if you're reading this, you're amazing and I love you.]

4) Tremendously hip ambiance: brown leather couch-like benches, a working fireplace, soft candles a'flickering atop each table and oh-so-cool house music playing overhead.

5) DELICIOUS hummus [NOTE: I'm a certified hummus aficionado] and warm, authentic, bubbly pita bread.  Holy garbonzo bean gods, I have entered chickpea heaven!

6) OH, and who can forget dessert!  FREE dessert, that is.  That's right, Senor Willoughbejo hooked us hot chickaritas up with some decadent cheesecake and homemade ice cream.  Babababoooyeah!

Terzo, I WILL be coming back!!  Bravo!  Bravo!
author: Katie C.

description:
I'm so torn between giving this place 3 or 4 stars.... and here's why.. I'll start with the good.

3 reasons for 4 stars:
1) Clean, clean restaurant. Granted this place is brand spanking new, I love how it gives off such a clean, fresh, and cozy feeling. 
2) Fresh, quality food. Everything was made with simple ingredients, but so delicious and flavorful. Highlights:

Bruschetta: Served on crispy bread with thick slices of tomatoes and fresh basil. The special part was that it was topped with a fried egg. YUM!

Chicken Spiedini: skewers with chunks of moist chicken, crispy bread cubes and onions

3) Perfect place for a LIGHT meal or snack. We left this place content. Not full or stuff. Definitely had room for dessert.

3 reasons for 3 stars:
1) Price. The price:portion ratio was definitely off. Each small plate was around $10-$13. You literally got 3 bites per dish. Between 3 girls, I only got one bite. =(

2) Menu selection: Although the food was fabulous, the menu was quite small. If you go with a group, you literally would have to order everything on the menu to have enough to eat.

3) Don't go here if you're starving. This place will not fill you up. Unless you order at least 3-4 plates JUST for yourself. No sharing.

Knowing these pros and cons.... go to Terzo at your own discretion.
author: Denise L.

description:
I had an unexpectedly delicious and unexpectedly expensive meal here.  The tapas were really tasty and unique, but damn those portions were small.  If you come with more than one other person and the server throws down something you want on the table, be prepared to fight for it.  

The service was extremely attentive and honestly really stellar.  From the moment we walked in we were completely taken care of and we didn't even have a reservation.  The hostess, bar tender, and server all went out of their way to check in with us.  Our server offered us wine samples and didn't rush our table at all.  I was actually impressed with how knowledgeable she was with respect to the wine list and menu items, etc.

The atmosphere is really cozy as well.  Can I just say I love the fact that they have a bookshelf full of books?  I don't know if anyone uses it, but it's pretty unique.  I give them a star just for that.
author: Dubs W.

description:
I want to give this a 4.5 - it was terrific.  Not as good as it gets 5*, but our overall experience couldn't have gotten much better.

The food was very very good, the ambiance was fun and lively, the wait staff excellent and we had a great time eating at a table in the bar area.  

Limited menu, but all very good.   A tiny bit pricey for some things ($8 soup), but paying for ambiance and service.  We would go back.
author: michael d.

description:
This is a stylish restaurant with a good wine selection and menu not much more different than other restaurants around the city.

What makes it different 
- The food is really good. Every small plate we ordered was excellent. The dessert was good too - not too indulgent but very tasty. 
- The ambience is great. It's ideal to bring a date to this place.
- My friend is a regular so we received very good service. 

I would give it a 4 and a half stars if it was possible.
author: Kunal S.

description:
The staff was friendly enough and the environment cozy but the food was nothing special. The waiter suggested the chicken, figs, and halibut. I ended up ordering the halibut and figs. 

The halibut was served with garbanzo beans and tasted similar to the dozen other times I have ordered halibut. Simplicity is fine and actually welcome but this ended up being nothing but average. However, the figs wrapped with prosciutto were great! Although a bit greasy (understandable given the ingredients) there was definitely flavor to this dish, unlike the halibut. Average food bordering on good usually will warrant 3 stars. However, I have to deduct a star because of the dessert.

I ordered the Midnight cake which came with a small side of coffee ice cream. The cake tasted like the prepackaged ones at Safeway. I wanted to ask someone, "Wow, did you bake this yourself?" However, this was a restaurant and not some house party. So, I was unimpressed.

Given the number of high reviews listed I will probably given it another shot. 

On another note, there is only one communal table, not two. Beside the communal table is a wall mirror which they keep spotlessly clean.  While I was waiting at the bar I kept seeing the reflection and wondering why the hell they had two communal tables.
author: Shawn T.

description:
here we go....another restaurant that just is a must to go try out!!! for those of you that don't know what TERZO means it means 3..and it symbolizes the owner's third restaurant. The people in there are all sooooooooooooo fun and nice....i guess i'm going thru a phase where i'm finally meeting some nice and "welcoming" waiters/waitresses.  yipppeee for me!

Anyways, we just so happened to be sitting next to the owner that night and she told us exactly what were the best sellers on the menu and they were all yummy!  i highly recommend the halibut...the chicken, their beef..and don't forget their crispy onions....but bear in mind these dishes are all quite small...so if you have a larger party..you might want to order another one if it's not enuf....but don't order too much cuz u have to save room for dessert...their almond cake with strawberries were amazing! We ended up ordering two of those!!!  Their lemon tart was good 2.....bon apetite.
author: Mee-stique K.

description:
Boring food, sucky staff, it makes me sad to be in this place.  I won't give a place a bad review if I've only been there once (which I suppose puts me squarely in the top 1% of yelpers in the benefit-of-the-doubt category - just sayin), but I've been to this place twice with my mom and once for snacks at the bar, and hoo boy it just blows it all over town.  Seems like a bunch of people had a good time, so I won't waste your time with griping, but Terzo (much like Absinthe) has just screwed me too many times.  Bartender was hostile and defensive, server weirded me out, and I swear I saw one of the waitresses start to cry over at the bus station cuz the other servers were getting all Mean-Girls on her.  And when the best thing out of my double-digits small plates is some hummus and crackers......

bummer.
author: Nick P.

description:
I went to Terzo for the second time last night w/ a group of girlfriends after the opera and fell in love w/ this restaurant all over again.  While "Terzo" means third in Italian, this restaurant is now #1 on my list of favorite neighborhood places.  From the exposed brick walls and dimly lit NYC style decor to the lively groups enjoying their meals, this place has it all.  We ordered nearly one of everything on the menu, but a few stood out.   While the larger plates like the snapper in parchment paper were beautifully displayed, I preferred the smaller plates.  The hummus and warm pita bread along with the baked goat cheese were delicious.  And the 3 bottles of Presecco helped it all go down so smoothly.  

Just as stellar as the food was our waiter...Williby, we love you!!! From his excellent service, to his sense of humor, to his fabulously chic glasses, Williby will not disappoint you.  Make your reservations today!
author: Julie S.

description:
A Michael Bauer disappointment.  Someone either slipped some goodness in his dish or giving him good licks!

Don't go here, not even worth writing about...

Food was good and interior locations was nice, all else was a distraction to hurry out of there soon...including the hostess and waitress.  Wish I was told that my reservations made two weeks in advance only allotted for a quick glass of water and no walk to the ladies room...
author: Mayah C.

description:
I have since been back several times, and not a single disapointment. Just kind of want some of that pasta I had that one time, I know and love how there are always new things on the menu, but that rigatoni with that tomato sauce, I can never forget about.
Last time I visited, I had ordered the chicken, which literally melted in your mouth, this time around we also had the muscles as an appitizer, they were ofcourse fantastic, as everything else is on the menu. 
The best part is I can eat here every day...
author: yana Z.

description: We tried this place out last night and I was happy with the overall experience. The place was nicely decorated and smelled of fresh Tuberous. We tried several things on the menu and I loved the fennel soup, the tri-tip steak. I didn't care for the marrow..it was much too greasy and not enough substance. I can't wait to go back and try some more dishes...oh..and one should mention their gorgeous bathroom...I could probably bath in the sink...
author: Mimi T.

description:
came here for a work dinner/party and from what i could remember, everything was great.  we got the big communal table and at first we thought it was a little too wide but after a few glasses of wine, who cares?  the ambiance was nice with good lighting and fireplace.  i did pay extra attention to the music because other yelpers have complained that it was little loud but i didn't think so.

we ordered most of the menu and everything was awesome.  the dishes that really stood out were the brussel sprouts, the lamb shoulder, the pear bruschetta (!!!), the calamari, and that flourless chocolate cake!  the chicken skewers were tasty as well but mostly because of the bread it was grilled with!   oh, the olive oil that accompanied the bread was really good as well.  oh, how did i forget about those meatballs??!!!  

plus, the service was outstanding.  i can't remember our server's name but she was really attentive and kept our wine glasses filled.  :)  

definitely coming back.
author: Sally T.

description:
Went to this new joint a couple of nights ago with some girlfriends.  Aside from the fact that my friend to the right was dealing with a major illness in her family and my friend to the left was in the midst of a nervous breakdown (and when I say "in the midst", I mean tears streaming down her face while sitting at the bar at Terzo), I remained optimistic about enjoying my meal - and hopefully, eventually, my company.  

We sat at the bar because there were no seats available - and because, quite frankly, we really wanted to put the apparent misery of our company on full display for all other patrons.  There is a small tapas selection, which was good (we had the spanish cheese and quince and the tortilla); though I do wish that some restaurant/bar in SF would actually do a tapas bar the right way with toothpicks and napkins on the floor and such, but I digress . . .

The menu is very small.  This  is not a place to come if you are very hungry, but it is a great place for three chicks to enjoy a lite meal and some vino.  We had the halibut, the chicken, and the lasagna.  The halibut was fantastic and the lasagna was really good as well - really thinly sliced layers.  Good wine list.  I also liked the ambiance of the place.  And, this neighborhood definitely needs more good dining options outside of pizza chains and bar food.  If I could give it a 3.5, I would have.  

I will definitely be back. . . . hopefully, with less drama.
author: Amy K.

description:
This was my first visit to Terzo. I was able to make a reservation on OpenTable for a Saturday night.  We were promptly seated by a gracious hostess. We were seated in the small room in the back, which was great, since we wanted to talk and the front room was so noisy.  Someone took drink orders and our waiter, Willoughby, came to explain the menu which is all small plates. 

My gay friend from Dallas started flirting with the waiter.  He smiled, told us he was straight and never missed a beat.  He continued to be charming and helpful.

He recommended about 8 plates for the three of us.  We ended up ordering nine plates and everything was delicious.  The crispy onions, similar to onion rings, were made with red onions.  They were great, but didn't come with a dipping sauce.  The Chicken Spiedini was fabulous and was served on a skewer.  The tab for the food for three people came to about $90, but we were satisfied and thought it was well worth it.

You almost have to use the valet service ($10) because it is so hard to park in that neighborhood at night.

I'll be Baaack!

(Rosies, across the street is owned by the same company)
author: Bart V.

description:
This place is phenomenal.  We went quite randomly one Friday night because a friend couldn't get reservations at the spot we really wanted to go, and in retrospect, I couldn't be happier that the other place was full.  Terzo was a bit crowded when we got there for our 9 pm reservation, but the hostess did everything she could to have us seated ASAP (and I'm always happy to have a glass of wine in the bar anyway).

Once we sat down, the experience continued to wow everyone I was with.  We ordered everything the server recommended to us on the menu, and not one single plate disappointed.  I'm not exaggerating...everything we put in our mouth was absolutely amazing.  We couldn't even have a real conversation because we were so busy raving about the food.  I'd encourage anyone and everyone to give this place a try.  And I'd be a great date spot too!
author: Dale M.

description:
VEGETARIAN REVIEW

Really enjoyable.  I'd never been, but I guess the Washington Post wrote a nice little blurb about it, and my friends from that neck of the woods had made reservations for Thursday night at 7:30.  We were a little late, but the hostess was super-friendly and accommodating.  The inside is a nice space, full of clean lines, and it wasn't too busy.

We ordered a variety of small plates, including the fried onions (oh, light and crisp and not too greasy), olives (ohhh, delicious, marinated in herbs and full of flavor), and the squash, cut into 1/4-inch sections with the skin still on in the back, with pumpkin seeds (I could try this at home, but not without a _lot_ of attention and care to fresh ingredients).  My friends enjoyed the meat stuff, but I didn't feel deprived, and we all made short work of the bread and hummus dish.  

Our waiter was fun, attentive, and had great suggestions.  When my friend finally picked from the dessert wine menu, the waiter allowed us to chat our way through dessert (a shot of Euro-style hot chocolate hit the spot) then brought a swallow of the other wine under consideration. 

Probably not worth visiting if you're vegan -- dairy fat abounds in the veggie dishes.
author: KJ M.

description:
I hate the marina....and all who inhabit it, however I donned my bio-hazard suit and waded into the evil to go to this place on a friends recommendation. Despite the risk of being zombified I am so glad we went to this place. It was awesome.

The small plates here are delicious and they have a very good wine selction. Their hummus rivals some of the best I have ever had and their crispy onions are tastttty. If you like salads go for their arugula salad. 

I didn't have any entrees but from the quality of their small plates I can only imagine they are wonderful. This is a great place to meet and have a drink and a small plate before going out into the night.

As always, you will never get parking in the marina so put that dream to bed. Reservations are recommended and the place is kind of small but not in a bad way.

Enjoy your time there but if you hear Michael Jackson's Thriller start to play....run......the zombies are coming. I hate you marina.
author: Josh J.

description: Still a sold dinner spot for yummy food, great service and good ambiance. Got there for a late dinner & told they were closing the kitchen at 9pm so we quickly placed our order and didn't ever feel rushed even though we were the last people in the place by the time we left. We split the King Salmon w/ tons of snap peas+asparagus & the Penne Rigate.  Tried the Panna Cotta  for dessert and was ok, but would probably get another dessert next time. Didn't know about the 50% off wine until seeing it on YELP now. Oh well, next time.
author: Mel A.

description: What a special little gem! The food was wonderful, fresh, hot from the kitchen/grill, and beautifully presented. There were four of us and we tried 8 dishes...and each one was great! Our waiter was helpful and attentive and friendly...even when he realized we had a gluten-free, dairy-free member of the group! He had great suggestions and accommodations. We will definitely go back...but do get a reservation since it's not a huge place. See you there!
author: Marg R.

description: Love this place. So cool and great food! The wines are also very good and not your usual run of the mill. Hip crowd. Worth a visit!
author: Annie E.

description:
Good call by my lady to stop in and grab some awesome plates.. Nicole our server had a great attitude and was on top of it.. 

food: well above averege: Great Wine special help keep that tab down.  Clean & cool place.. I'd go back..
author: Dutch B.

description: Very classy joint!  Excellent wine choices and service! Erin was absolutely on top of it and sweet!  The food is amazing!  The steak and pumpkin cheesecake was to die for!
author: Lilo B.

description:
This was okay, and when I say okay, that is just what it is.

Needless to say, we sat in the back room and the ambiance was great, yet as we walked out my mom hung back behind and apparently ripped the manager a new one.  Who knew?  I thought everything was okay.  Fish was good, yet VERY expensive for the wee portion you receive.
author: Nicole F.

description: A gorgeous little spot in the Marina. I love the service here (very consistent any time I have come - attentive, knowledgeable, friendly, unobtrusive) and all of the food. Try the pork tenderloin, you will dream about it for daaaays.
author: Lisa P.

description: This a delicious and charming place.  The menu changes daily!  The small plates are great for sharing, and everything was delicious.  The space is modern and new, and the staff was attentive.  The beets were particularly good - they strain whole milk yogurt into a thick deliciousness.  Also recommend the pita bread.
author: Amy H.

description:
I really like this place. It took a second time to figure it out but I really like this place. The first time I went with friend - and perhaps it was what we ordered - I thought it was OK. We were adventurous and tried the bone marrow. I have had it before but cooked differently. The way Terzo cooked it, it was really oily. The sirloin steak and the pita bread was yummy!

The second time I went with my honey and we loooved every dish. The fried egg over the asparagus was interesting but really good. We also had the halibut, the steak, the sausage, and of course the pita bread! Yum yum. We also tried the ginger cake. They also have a great wine list!
author: Jen R.

description:
It took me a while to get there because I had mixed reviews from my trusted sources.  My restauranteur & co. friends thought it wasn't up to par with our other faves.  Other friends, including a wine pro, highly recommended it as one of his recent finds.

So, I decided to crash the place on a Saturday night without a reservation.  A friend got there at 6 pm and was able to hold a table by the window for 6:30 while she waited for me with a drink.  To me, that was a huge browny point since not all host(ess)s are that accommodating.

We couldn't have asked for a more perfect evening for two friends who just wanted to catch up without the fuss of loud diners and bar flies.  The server recommended a bottle of Rioja, which we enjoyed to the very last drop.

As unusual as it sounds, beet & avocado salad was actually very tasty.  The steamed mussels and Nieman ranch beef were both excellent as well.  We decided to jump to dessert, flourless chocolate cake with five spice ice cream - speechless and happy.

Our server, last but least, was one of the most friendly I've had - a beautiful brunette from Prague who was very sweet, attentive without being overbaring.
author: Staci C.

description:
There are those occasional evenings where tentative plans and loose schedules require flexibility in dining. I have a few go-to places I keep in the back of my mind that are well-located, have a staff that can roll with it and, above all, good food. Prominent in that short list is Terzo.

Last night Cheryl was coming from an ArtPoint evening at the de Young and I was coming off the Yelp event at the Space Gallery and we were hoping to grab dinner together. I headed over to Terzo, grabbed a chair at the bar and waited for my girl. I downed a glass of Gigondas and had a bowl of the Sweet Corn Soup with Chives & Creme Fraiche. It really hit the spot although the wine was a bit heavy for it (which I knew going in but...). Cheryl arrived and we the bartender found us a table.

The rest of the evening was classic Terzo, a true small-plates restaurant. A series of dishes arrived - Hummus with House Made Pita & Za'atar (always great), Grilled Flatbread with Tahini, Feta, Roasted Cherry Tomatoes & Herbs  (really good), Lori's Spicy Italian Sausage with Soft Polenta & Peppers & Onions (actually liked the polenta even more than the sausage), and Grilled Tesa Wrapped Figs with Wild Arugula, Saba & Olive Oil (Cheryl loves figs). She had a glass of the Garnacha, El Chaparral Old Vines, Navarra, Spain, 2005.

The pacing of the dishes was perfect and service was friendly (although maybe just a bit too much checking to see if all was good which I really can't complain too loudly about). The wine list is good (until recently it carried Chateau Musar, one of my faves and hard to find). The ambiance is terrific and there is a good size common-table area. They have valet parking and the location, as I mentioned, is great. Terzo has become one of the places that is top of mind when I ask "where d'ya wanna eat tonight?".
author: Gary C.

description:
4.5 stars ... hosted by Ray of RayPacific.com (if you want to invest a minimum of $250K in an excellent Hedge Fund please let me know)
I was looking forward to a night of fine foods and fine wines.  Well fine company too, yah ~ and I wasn't disappointed on any of the 3 counts.
Most of the delish dishes mentioned in other Yelp reviews, found their way to our table and boy they have a way with fried onions ... or maybe they were just "easy" onions ... bad joke ... onion sluts!  (On menu as:  Crispy Onions) Just be sure to order the battered and fried (dazed and confused?) onions.  The  Marinated olives and garbanzo bean paste thing (Hummus with House Made Pita and Za'atar)  were really good, then came the Grilled Niman Ranch Pork Loin,  Grilled Asparagas with marinated feta and Greek Olive Oil were just right, the Grilled Montana Ranch Grass Fed Skirt Steak was chewy tasty, the chicken kabobs were about the best chicken kabobs ever because the chunks of chicken were seasoned just right and virtually melted in your mouth.  Hand Cut Noodles with Early Girly Tomato Puree, Mascarpone and Basil was properly toothsome and tasty, the Beer Battered Fried True Cod (beats the heck out of "fake cod," right?)  and Slow Cooked Artichokes with Blood orange, Crispy Serrano Ham and Regina Olive Oil ... everything done to relative perfection ... 
This table really sprung for some super high falutin' red wines ... facing multiple wine glasses with various high end wines while family style dining with quite the illustrious crowd made missing March Madness basketball an amenable proposition.  Service was quite superb, didn't get any of the server's names but kudos to all.  Not that well-versed in Mediterranean food but I know good food when I encounter it and this is good food, they really aim to please.  Highly recommended ... okay now let's discuss investing your money ...
author: Terry A.

description: I've been here a few times and this week's visit was the best yet.  Always liked Terzo but didn't go out of my way of it.  This experience will bring us back repeatedly.  Yummy and unusual bruschette (heirloom tomato and pesto topped with a fried egg); salmon with garbanzo beans; a melon/prosciutto/ciltantro salad; Lori's spicy sausage with polenta.  We almost licked every plate.  And for the level of service and food thought the prices very reasonable -- we spent close to $200 for two of us, but that included a $50 bottle of wine and 2 glasses of dessert wine, and a dessert (apricot crisp with ice cream).  We went over the top because we were enjoying it so much.
author: Robin W.

description: Hadn't been here in a few years and have to admit I was pleasantly surprised. They've really stepped it up. Everything we had was delicious. Service was great and food was great. Will definitely be going back.
author: K C.

description:
Last time I entered this building was 10 years ago, and it was Pane e Vino. I would say the transformation is pretty incredible, no longer resembling the former space. Updated and hip there was a nice vibe upon entering.

Had no advance info on the menu, but was not so surprised to see it is a small plates menu focused on Mediterranean ingredients somewhat fused with California influences. Out of the 10 or so dishes the 3 of us ordered, the standout favorites were the spicy mussels (too small a portion - we had 2 order a 2nd round), the sea bass with charmoula and garbanzo beans (by far the best), and the porcini and mache salad with ricotta salata. Otherwise everything was ok - not super special. Wine list is interesting - I had a very nice cremant rose sparkling wine to start (will need to find the producer name and buy it for home).

Just had a couple bites of the gianduja pot de creme dessert which was nice and creamy but perhaps a bit too cold to taste the flavors.

For some reason there were only about 2 male diners in the entire restaurant that night - what is up with that??? Bad ratios in Cow Hollow for sure.
author: Mariangela S.

description: Wonderful dinner, fun and creative menu with lots to choose from for sharing or entree. Loved the meatballs and calamari. The service was outstanding, Cat was our server. Great neighborhood restaurant with all the qualities of top rated dining
author: cheri w.

description:
I decided to have my girlfriend's birthday dinner here after getting a few recommendations from my friends (we were new to the city).I made the reservation by phone a month in advanced, but when I called to confirm it was lost. I can't blame the location since I made the reservation by phone and so far in advance. Luckily the GM worked his magic and shifted things around to fit us in - nice feat for a party of 10.  I'm glad he did because we had an amazing time. We decided to have the wait staff order for the group and they didn't let us down. The waiter did a great job of bringing out a variety of small and large plates for the group to sample. For the price we paid, we all left feeling extremely satisfied. We got to try two or three of most of their top plates and by the end of the night we were all stuffed. I'd recommend this place for a birthday dinner (at the communal table), for a date night, or for a casual dinner with friends. 

I'd recommend the meatballs, the apple/feta salad, and the fig small plates!
author: Adrian G.

description:
If I was in a bad mood, I would just say that the architect who redid this place should run the kitchen and get rid of the current chef. But since I am in a good mood, you might as well read on....

star worthy:
The hummus and pita bread are excellent,  the salad, the halibut and the midnight cake are good.

not star worthy:
The mussels. Out of a *tiny* plate, we had about 20% that really tasted just plain *bad*. 
My beef was served cold and I don't think this was on purpose, but rather because it sat on a counter too long.
Having to request bread in this type of place is just, well, out of place in my book. If you don't want to waste it and offer it by default on all tables, at least ask us if we would like some. Having to ask makes it sound like we are hurting your margins. Please, this place must generate margins fatter than a Michael Milken insider trade.

All in all, and despite my initial comment, the place is pleasant, and the staff attentive. Someone previously said something like "go there when you're not hungry". That's a bit harsh, but I can relate and that tells me something is not quite right when the place is actually a restaurant, as opposed to, say, a bar.
author: Frederic B.

description:
I always like to go out on the town after getting my hair coiffed, so my boyfriend and I had an early dinner here last night.  Love the warm cozy atmosphere here.  Our waiter Ron was also super friendly and knew his stuff.

We scored a nice bottle of Beaujolais for $20 since all wines $40 and under are half price Sunday-Thursday.  However, to our surprise, each person had to order either one entree or two small plates in order to get the wine half price.  We had originally planned on only ordering three smalls but bumped it up to four so we would be eligible for the discount.  (Hey, why not?)

Our fave was the Mediterranean mussels in sherry sauce.  The mussels were big, juicy and tender.  Divine!

Next best were the roasted winter veggies with brown butter, sage and pecorino.  Yum!

The fried egg and truffle bruschetta sounded intriguing but was only  "good" in our opinion.

We were disappointed with the panzarotto (which is like a calzone).  Thought it could have had more ham and the crust should have been crispier.  Plus, they should have served the marinara sauce in a cup on the side instead of putting it all over the plate under the panzarotto which made the crust a bit soggy on the bottom.  But it didn't stop us from scarfing the whole thing down.

And then my boyfriend (like always) insisted that we get dessert.  So I caved in and we ordered the Tuscan bread pudding with dried cherries and caramel sauce.  Yes!
author: Michelle E.

description: Mostly a small plates / share kinda place, but there are a few large plates on the menu. The share thing is echoed by one of those trendy communal table setups. For small plates, we shared: hummus/pita, calamari, beet salad, pork meatballs and grilled asparagus. We also shared one large plate: chicken cacciatore. EVERY dish was outstanding! Terzo is my new favorite. Interestingly, the restaurant that used to occupy this space (Pane e Vino) used to be my fave too (until they moved to Union St. and went downhill). Must be some magic karma at this Steiner St. location that makes the food shine!
author: Robyn C.

description: Great restaurant for a date.  Shared small plates incl. hummus and house-made pita.
author: around town e.

description: I really enjoyed my experience for two on Friday. Definitely make a reservation, this place is packed. We were seated promptly by a very friendly man and our server, Ron, was AWESOME. Very helpful with he menu; there's so many options, sometimes you need help. All five plates we ordered were delicious; the pita they serve with the hummus is out of this world(!) and the figs were delightful. We ordered two desserts; the crumble was insane but the other we could do without. Totally forgot what it was. Wine menu is impressive. Overall, I give the experience  and food 5 stars... but... I was surprised how expensive the bill was for 2 people. Worth it... but still surprised.
author: Meredith R.

description: Went here for the second time this weekend. Enjoyed it much more than the first. I went with 5 other girls, so I had a chance to try many more dishes. The waiter was nice. I enjoyed the artichoke, the hummus and pita is very yummy, the salmon, the trout, the cold beef was so so, the calzone was not too exciting, the flatbread was pretty good. It all came out to about $25 per person w/o alcohol. Nice venue, but it seemed to be an older crowd.
author: Caroline L.

description:
the menu is always changing, but whatever pasta they have on the menu is usually a home run.  i've had: spaghetti with fresh cherry tomatoes and sweet corn (sounds weird, but was great), and linguini with wild mushrooms and parmigiano cream.

the ambience is cozy (wood and cool lighting) and the restaurant is tucked away off of the business that is union st.
author: Priscilla T.

description: I'm pretty sure the best hummus in the city is at Terzo. For special occasions, I used to order it takeout for parties I hosted. We always get great service and have found most of their dishes to be excellent.
author: Marina N.

description:
I have been here once and we literally ordered everything on the menu.  The plates were really small which is good if you like variety, bad if you are hungry.  I think this is called Italian tapas.  The food was incredibly fresh, but didn't seem too innovative or interesting.  One plate was sliced squash with olive oil and lemon.  The restaurant is crowded and not having a reservation, we were stuck in a table against the wall, in an aisle, next to the kitchen.  The chef is really nice and came out to our table to greet and make small talk with us.  Hence, I cannot really knock the place.  I will have to go back another time to give a real review.

Consider this review preliminary notes.
author: apple r.

description:
The food was pretty good ( a tad too salty on a couple plates) but the service was lacking.  Albeit they had only been open for a week when we went there.  We had a group of 7 - ordered a fair amount of plates, which arrived in fits and starts.  Our "main" server was on the inattentive side.  If she would have been on her toes they could have easily got 2 more bottles of wine out of us.  Hits for us were the hummus, marrow bones, and crispy onions.  We enjoyed it all (just about got one of everything on the menu) but the salad was over-salted.

Plates are tiny - you'll need min. 3 per person esp. if you have men at the table.

I'd go again hoping they've worked the kinks out.
author: darla s.

description: Excellent food, atmosphere and service. Nicole, our server, was accommodating, knowledgeable and attentive. Being a vegan, she said she got me covered and I was able to eat more items on the menu then I thought. Delicious beets, roasted squash, hummus/pita and a vegetable medley (the kale was out of this world, but a tad oily.) She also selected our wines and the Pinot Grigio was outstanding - one of the best whites I've had. The overall experience was very pleasant, BUT I do hate the Marina (yuppy central) - let's just pick this restaurant up and move it to another district. :)
author: S. M.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place every time I come back home to the Bay but just never had the time. But this time around, I made it!

Lovely ambiance. Warm without pretentious. I love the communal table in the center of the place. This is certainly a place to go with some great friends, have a bottle of wine and some small plates!!!  Or to go on dates!! The service was wonderful!

Their wine list was quite impressive. There were some Spanish and Italian wines that I wanted to try the next time I'm there

The food.... HOT DAMN!!! There was nothing that I did not love... I would have love to see pork on the menu but then again..that's just me and my love of swine.  OK so back to the menu... it was a perfect balance of showcasing the fresh regional produces with the home cooking of the Mediterranean region. It was a harmonious match!
We had the early girl tomatoes, roasted butternut squash, chicken spiedini and crispy onions and spaghetti with chanteralle mushrooms! It was certainly a perfect amount without overdoing it! 

I can't wait to come here again!!!
author: Mich Q.

description: My husband and I love Terzo. Amazing, fresh food with focus on organic and local when possible. Dishes change with the seasons, and we recently ordered the Fig Bruschetta which was off the charts delicious. Good wines, and we've been served by Ron numerous times and he is always incredibly attentive, friendly, and great with order recommendations. Drinks are kept filled, plates and utensils are kept fresh. It's a go-to spot for date night in the Marina/Cow Hollow.
author: Marta H.

description: Healthy pours of wine and tasty food.  This Tapas restaurant has wonderful seasonal foods and while semi-small they are still great sharing plates.  The wine selection is pretty extensive and they are willing to give you a small pour to try a wine.  Great ambiance inside and friendly waitstaff.  Great date place with the wife.
author: Dave L.

description: Have been to Terzo many times and had a good experience.  But last night we had reservations at 10pm for 6 of us.  They call me 5 minutes before our reservation and tell me the kitchen will be closing and we need to place our order right when we get there.  We get there and the waitress start to badger my party to order, we literally just sat at the table and they had not poured the water yet.  I ask to speak to the manager and he starts to defend this behavior and stated that it was my fault for making a late reservation, I mentioned to him that if he had called me earlier and stated he did not want a 10pm reservation we could have made other arrangements.  We had to leave without having dinner given that no one wanted to eat under the durress of ordering as if we were at McDonald's. Very Unprofessional on his part and I can't imagine we will go back.
author: David P.

description:
Terzo is one of those places my husband and I love to go when we just want something predictably good. We've eaten there several times now and the food has always been tasty. I like the small plates because it lets you try a bunch of different things. 

Last week we stopped in for a glass of wine each and a few fun plates. We always start with the hummus here. The hot, herb-seasoned pita slices they server with it are so incredibly delicious. I've tried to recreate the effect at home, but have yet to be successfuly unfortunately. We then shared the roasted artichokes with romesco sauce. OMG, this was one of the best dishes I've ever had! I could have just eaten a huge plate of that. Both of us had our own small plates of the spaghetti dish to finish and thought it was very good. 

The atmosphere at this place is nice too. There is a tall communal table right behind the bar that is fun if you're feeling in a social mood. But there are also many intimate tables as well. It's really a great date spot. 

The bar area is okay, but I think it's a little small and I don't like the fact that there are no backs on the barstools. I've eaten a meal there before and it gets a little uncomfortable after a while without being able to lean back. 

I've always found the service here to be quite good and the waitstaff to be friendly and attentive.
author: Christine P.

description:
Had a fine dinner here: hummus with pita bread and za'atar, fried egg bruschetta, grilled sea bass with garbanzo beans and charmoula. 

Loved the lighting and decor of the place, service was good.
author: Genie J.

description:
I've been here two times, once with work and once with friends visiting from out of town.

WORK - I wasn't paying for it so I had no idea how pricey Terzo really was.  I loved the ambiance and the food was fantastic.

VISITING FRIENDS - I brought visiting friends here based on my previous dining experience.  Oh boy did I feel awful once we started ordering...  you needed at least 4 small plates per person, at least.  Add in a couple of bottles of wine and dessert - cha-ching, cha-ching!   Sad thing is that I was still hungry when we got home so I made a grilled cheese sandwich. :(
author: Jess R.

description:
Great food. Great wines. Great atmosphere. Great service. The fireplace gives the entire place a warm, cozy feeling. 

Been here a few times and can say that I've only been let down once...and that was50% due to the waitress' dessert recommendation and 50% due to my dining companions.

The skirt steak is amazing...melts in your mouth tasty. The cannelloni warms your body.  I regret not ordering the spaghetti carbonara last time after seeing the women at the table next to me eat it.  Guess I'll need to make a mental note for next time...
author: Todd S.

description: Never less than amazing! Seasonal ingridients, Fresh Fresh and so tasty! Menu staples that I look forward to...The BEST fresh made hummus and Pita, Pork Loin always good, fresh pasta's awesome! Big selection of affordable wine's...and great ambiance. My go to place!
author: Heather S.

description:
Great dinner last night - this restaurant has come a long way since my first visit soon after opening. Every dish was creative, and simply worked. 

Two of us shared 3 dishes, and it was absolutely enough! 

*Roasted Diane Yams with Brown Butter & Sweet Spice Gastrique $9 (Gastrique is similar to a thick balsamic vinegar) 
*Roasted Artichokes with Blood Oranges & Olive Vinaigrette $9 
*Grilled Steelhead Salmon with Garbanzos & Charmoula $26 (Charmoula is like a pesto) 
*Tempranillo-Cabernet Sauvignon "Rívola", Abadía Retuerta, Castilla y León, Spain, 2005 @ $36/bottle (This wine is excellent... and only $36!) 

Next time I'll try the Free Range Chicken Spiedini (and here's the recipe from Mark Gordon himself Mark Gordon: http://tinyurl.com/dyq2l7) 

Thanks Washington (our waiter) who provided us with excellent service.
author: Becky S.

description: Delicious food and wine, and the decor is really charming. Terzo is tucked away in a quieter part of Cow Hollow, but it's still easy walking distance to other shops and bars.
author: C B.

description: The staff here was so nice and the food was really really good. This is a great place to meet at the bar and have a drink .
author: amy r.

description: Terzo has stellar onion rings, thin and piled high, enough for our party of four as we started off with a crisp bottle of Prosecco.  The waitress selected an earthy red for our small plates and we shared Sunday dinner in a busy but not loud space, perfect for a reunion with friends celebrating our move back to SF from Portland.
author: mark h.

description: A sexy new pan-Mediterranean wine bar brought to you by the same owners of the famed Rose's Cafe and Rose Pistola. Terzo, their third venture, serves up tasty small plates which change on a weekly basis. Lucky enough to attend their opening, we sampled some amazing dishes, including the 'must try' steamed clams and chicken skewers - (But I'd pass on the bone marrow....a little too experimental for even myself) paired with some amazing wines (try the Fritz Pinot Noir from Russian River - my favorite!) Apparently the wine list will be an ever-changing 60 bottle list. The atmosphere was cozy, sexy, relaxed - great place to meet friends or take a date.  We sat at the communal table, which made for a very fun evening. A great addition to the Marina neighborhood.
author: Melissa W.

description:
Terzo is a great new spot for us Marina/Cow Hollow groupies. It's pretty small though, so reservations can be tricky to get. 

The menu is set up with terrific small plates with a lot of flavor. I went with a few friends so we got to sample a lot of things, but too many to list out here. I hear they change the menu fairly frequently, and don't remember all that we got, but some of the highlights were steamed mussels with toasts to dip (OMG, so good) and a spinach lasagna.

We had great service, everyone from the bartender to the servers to the bussers were friendly, prompt and efficient.
author: Dariana R.

description:
I really wanted to love this restaurant, but the food was so salty it was almost unbearable. Even something simple like sea bass with garbanzo beans was drenched in what I am sure was an organic, french salt of provenance.  I'd rather eat at A16 for wonderful italian food, or Coco500 as someone else mentioned for modern small plates. Or even Roses Cafe across the street is a better choice.  

Still, many redeeming qualities including - lovely space, very attentive service and an excellent selections of wine by the glass. 

We ate rapini that was pureed with fresh ricotta. Nice! (& Salty).  Spinach with poached egg and bits of pancetta. sea bass (sent back), cold roast beef, and a fried calzone type thing with mozarella and a marinara sauce that saved us from going home hungry. 

It's frankly the *perfect* place to go meet for wine (no hard liquor there) and have a bite or two before going home for dinner or our somewhere else for a real meal. When the kitchen fine tunes itself it will be worth another star (or possibly two!)
author: Mark T.

description:
I think I avoid the Marina even more than I avoid North Beach - for very different reasons of course. However, the entire dining experience at Terzo from food to service was very good.

My wife and I were a tad late - she had just gotten rear-ended on her commute home before taking me out on a mid-week "date" to this surprise location.  However, we had a glass of wine at the bar and were able to relax while waiting for a table to come available. I had a great Cab - the Liparita, Napa 2000.

Our waiter was extremely enthusiastic, friendly and helpful. He would discreetly point out neighboring dishes so we could get visuals...His suggestions were all right on...We especially enjoyed the chicken Spiedini (two skewers) and Panzarotto (a semi-light Calzone).

While small plate places are all the range - and can get quite expensive - Terzo's portions seemed to be just right for two people to share 3 + dessert and not leave broke.

Aside from having to listen to the woman next to us brag to her friend about how well she married etc. etc., the dining experience was much better than what I expected. Almost enough for me to return to this 'hood on my own...well, maybe not.
author: masugu m.

description:
I'm always telling my friends that I have everything I need in the 5 block radius of Union St. forgetting that it's actually 6 blocks caused it goes down to Steiner... and hence never knew that Terzo was there!  Such a cute cozy little place with walls and walls of wine stack as decor.  We sat at the bar and shared a few plates.  

Food is tasty, service is great - bartender Mike was very attentive & helpful.  Hummus was yummy with really warm pita seasoned bread.  We ended up chatting (um, closing down the restaurant) having glasses & glasses of wine. 

Definitely see potential that this place will become my new neighborhood hangout!
author: Lily W.

description: Delicious food, friendly staff, nice atmosphere. I'd recommend this place if you're meeting a friend or going on a date - it's lively but not noisy. It is on the more expensive side, around $25-35/entree but it was definitely good food. Will definitely go back.
author: Maria Y.

description: Had a reservation and pulled up to the restaurant. No valet and not even a booth to indicate someone was just gone to park a car. Came outside after a $300 dinner to realize the restaurant called the police and had my car ticketed! Who calls the police on their own customers? Incredibly arrogant and unapologetic. Will never return.
author: Robert K.

description: Terzo has phenomenal food and a great wine selection. I highly recommend the meatballs and the rose. It is a great place to go on a first date... it is intimate, but not intimidating because it is always filled with people. Plus it's in a great location where you can walk on Union or Chestnut afterwards.
author: Kristin M.

description:
ate here for my very first time last night, and boy, did i enjoy myself! (too much, perhaps?)

the ambience of this italian/mediterranean tapas bar/restaurant is fantastic. the exposed brick, fun-yet-functional furniture, wood floors, fresh flowers, fireplace, and hanging edison bulbs had me dreaming of a home renovation...

for dinner, my fiance and i opted for a variety of small plates. apparently the menu changes frequently, but i'll let y'all in on our consumption anyway. (just in case y'all are curious.)

we ordered the porcini mushroom and fennel salad, baked squash blossoms with ricotta, pork meatballs with polenta, fried-egg topped bruschetta, and ooh, the crispy onions.

the porcini mushroom and fennel salad was beautiful in its presentation. the mushrooms and fennel were sliced very thin. but something about eating raw mushrooms always gets to me... a good, but not great dish.

and then came the baked squash blossoms filled with ricotta cheese. holy-crap, amazing!!! after eating the raw porcini mushroom and fennel salad, this was exactly what i was yearning for. warm, rich cheese filled veggies. so good. GET THIS!

next came the fried-egg-topped bruschetta. ORDER THIS! I repeat, ORDER THIS! each order serves up one piece, but the piece if large and can be shared if cut in half. the tomatoes were really sweet, the olive oil, perfection, and perfectly fried egg was so fun to polk... (yes, i like to pop my yolks and have the yellow gooey goodness coat my dishes.) YUMMMMMMMMY!

finally? out came the pork meatballs and crispy onions. the crispy onions here are to die for. soooooo addictive. you get an entire bowl (large bowl) for five bucks, and you just can't stop reaching for the suckers. YUM. CRACK SNACK!!! ORDER THIS! but the meatballs....... i couldn't help but think that they tasted a bit like chef boyardee meatballs..... a fancy version, of course, but seriously. order these if you want to confirm what i've just said. otherwise, skip.
 
for dessert, we shared terzo's vanilla buttermilk panna cotta with summer fruit. heavenly! while some may be freaked out by vanilla specks (insect poop?!), i swear the mere sight of vanilla bean specks makes any vanilla flavored dessert twice as good. as we consumed the dessert, my fiance kept asking me, "do you know how to make this?" yes, it was that good.

overall, a wonderful dining experience. i'll be back!
author: Debra C.

description:
loved this place, and even tho it sits smack dab in the middle of the marina, i would most definitely go back. i had a light dinner here with a girlfriend last week and just about everything about terzo was lovely. 

first off, we brought in her one year old baby girl with us and everyone was super nice and accommodating about that. not to be found in many nicer SF restaurants. the decor is warm and simple, with a polished earthiness. the light is perfect for a date, it's soft and yellow-y, everyone looks better. 

loved that they do half price bottles if you order 4 plates (i think this is time restrained so check before you go). we shared a crisp albarino from spain for like $20. can't beat that.  

they have a pretty nice selection of small plates for sharing, you could easily do a dinner this way, which is what we did. but there are also large plates if you prefer to be stingy...so, here's the food break down:

hummus and oil--amazing, super creamy, couldn't get enuf of it
beet salad--fresh, lovely, delicious, with pickled onions and creme fraiche
mushroom and cheese over fried polenta--definitely the stand out, melt in your mouth chanterelles, i died a little
the meatballs--this was the one miss for me. they were very plain, in a simple tomato sauce. kind of kid food which surprised me given how delish everything else was. 

also, since this is a medi place, why not bring a small dish of olives to start you off? that would have been perfection.
author: rachel p.

description:
This place lacks soul.  The decor is warm, but very predictable and devoid of any original character, as are the small plates, none of which blew me away -- except for the hummus and baked pita, which was insanely good.  

Otherwise, the place is cozy and our waitress was very pleasant, but the overall experience was somewhat disappointing.  I find that the food is more inspired at Rose's Cafe across the street.
author: marie m.

description:
I had my bday dinner there when it first opened and was very impressed. However, I have been back a few times and it has been getting worse and worse each time (and they keep changing the menu so I have a feeling I'm not the only one who feels this way). 

The staff could work on their personalities too...

Update: When back again, and it's worse...
author: Paige B.

description:
I really enjoyed my first meal at Terzo and it would have possibly gotten a fourth or fifth star but for the waiter suggesting to a us a $60 bottle of wine and not mentioning the cost up front (ahem). The space is beautiful and they have tables outside on nice nights. Bonus points of the girl who re-enacted what appeared to be a sex scene to her co-workers at the table next to us.
