The meatballs and the onion strings were VERY good.
author: Mike P.

description:
The first time I went here, I would have to agree with some complaints of service. Our waitress was either not too concerned about making a tip, or didn't feel that I would leave one she assumed she deserved for working there. The food was good, nice flavor, and a changing menu, we were just passing through getting a drink and appetizer before headed out to a dinner party. We only ordered three items way under her recommended plate number, after that she lost all interest in my table. And because I too was once a waitress, I realized how much I disliked her, but still left an okay tip, not the normal tip I would leave a person in the service industry. 

So why the four stars? I decided to give this place one more chance so my girlfriend and I go back, hoping the evil waitress is not there. Yes!! she's gone, and we get to pick our table, awesome, we want the one in the back. Great food and recommendations, excellent service, always nice to have a waiter buy you a dessert. The menu can have things that don't seem like it would be tasty but ask your waiter and he will show you the way. Don't come here expecting to get off cheap, wine start at 30 for the bottle, and those small plates add up.
author: Jackie L.

description: Terzo was a great spot for tapas and ambiance! Our group of three had several small plates and two mains, and it was plenty of food. The best dish of the night was also the simplest, the hummus with freshly baked pita. It was so delicious that we ordered a second serving of the pita. We also had the pork meatballs and mussels, which were also delish. For the main dishes we shared the Moroccan spiced chicken and the mahi mahi. The flavors on the chicken were unique and memorable, while the mahi mahi was accompanied by really lovely bitter greens. All in all this was a great meal, with great service. I'd definitely return.
author: Samantha S.

description: This place is incredible! I must confess I've been here countless times in the past couple of months. Every small plate I've ordered here has been a delicious pop of flavor - my favorites include the beets, chicken spiadini and hummus with pita. It's a great place to do a birthday gathering, date night or a fun night our with friends. You can share food, and get a great deal on wine on weeknights(bottles under $40 are half off!) Definitely try it out if you're looking for a European-inspired, cozy dinner spot with surprisingly inspired fare.
author: Keira A.

description: I want to start this off with saying that my bf and I are not cool enough for this place.  It is a very swanky wine bar by our house and I had heard good things about it so we went there last night for dinner.  We immediately judged the place as the cougar hen house but decided it was worth a shot.  We started with the hummus - it was delicious.  Their pita bread was seasoned with awesomeness and I could have eaten that all night.  The bf had the chicken which was great and I had the skirt steak.  I ate it slowly and enjoyed every bite.  We ended the night with the peach crisp with vanilla ice cream and I wanted to lick the bowl clean.  Our waitress was awesome and we enjoyed the dinner.  It is a very popular place so it's pretty loud in there but the food was great.
author: Arica V.

description:
I just had a wonderful dinner at Terzo last night.  The food was delicious, the atmosphere was intimate and warm, and the service was outstanding.  

Some of the highlights:

Pazarotto & Marinara - this is essentially the most yummy calzone i've ever eaten. after splitting the first one with my friend, i wanted to order another one just for myself.  the spicy, flavorful marinara sauce was a wonderful addition. 

Roasted Cauliflower - very tasty - the reggiano and walnuts tend to fall off the cauliflower, so make sure to scoop them up with every bite for a delicious combination of flavors.

Seared Monterey Calamari - very tasty and generous serving of borlotti beans.

Hummus - i love hummus and this was some good stuff.

The guests next to us had the skirt steak, spinach and crispy onions, all of which i want to try next time!
author: Jennifer Marie J.

description: Mark Gordon is a genius.  My husband and I dropped in for an early dinner on Saturday night and decided to go Veggie.  If you decide to visit in the near future you MUST try the Shaved Porcini Mushrooms.  The Roasted Beets are incredible every time I've tried them.  We also ordered the Arancini and the Gnocchetti which were also delighful.
author: Kattya B.

description:
Ate here last night and had a very nice experience.  Thought we were in for a problem at first.  Its a bit noisy and some of the tables are VERY close together, and we got seated at one of those.  Asked to get moved and were promptly and politely seated at a much better table.   Great service which proved to be true the entire night from everyone including the server, host and even busboy.  Very nice and attentive.

The food was really nice.  Hummus was spectacular, also had an arugula salad which tasted as if it was picked a few mins prior.  Very nice Sea Bass, a little rich.  The only thing that missed was the molten chocolate cake which was a little over cooked and not molten!  Mentioned that to the server who was apprecaitive, a bit surprised it wasnt taken off the bill, but no big deal.  

Prices aren't out of line with other places, but thats not to say its not expensive.

Wine by the glass list was very nice.  With a good range of wines and prices.  And choices not seen normally.

Very enjoyable meal
author: Robert G.

description: Great service, simple menu; either small or large plates. The items on the menu changes regularly, which is good since you get to taste what is in season. Food was decent, nothing really stood out as extraordinary. We sat outside for dinner so we can't really say much about the interior decor. But from the brief glance, it looks warm and inviting. Prices are standard, about $10 average for the small dishes and $20 average for large plates.
author: Jun W.
Monica P.

description:
Terzo definitely has potential, but there are some kinks they need to work out before it can become the fun, engaging dining experience it has the potential to be. First, the staff at Terzo gave our table the wrong bottle of wine. We ended up taking the bottle they gave us instead of the one we ordered, but there were no apologies from the staff.  Additionally, there seemed to be some confusion over which tables were free when we arrived, even though the place was nearly empty, and which dishes we had ordered.

On the plus side, the beets, meatballs, and pita with hummus were all tasty and worked well with the small/shared dishes concept. The beets were particularly flavorful (surprising, since I usually dislike beets and find them tasteless, or worse, tasting like only dirt) and complemented by a refreshingly tart cream/yogurt sauce and crunchy picked onions. The meatballs and pita were also good, but very heavy on the olive oil and rich. Sharing them is definitely the way to go!

Of the food, the only dish that wasn't uniformly delicious and rich was the chicken skewers. They chicken was slightly on the dry side, even though the bread chunks on the skewers were covered in olive oil.

Tucked away off of the main drag of the Marina, the decor at Terzo is modern without being cold, and the space is quiet and peaceful, good for conversation.
author: Bear S.

description: My favorite place in the neighborhood! Everything on their menu is creative and delicious. The appetizers change frequently and I never had one I didn't like.
author: Susanne S.

description: I've been coming here for years and its always outstanding. Terrzo maintains some great staples such as the humus and spiedini and supplements it with great seasonal dishes to keep it new. Great food, great service.
author: Skylar S.

description: Took 30 minutes to get seated. We had a reservation. Food was ok. Nothing special. There are many better places to eat in SF
author: Theodore N.

description:
Fabulous.

The menu changes daily b/c they work with a local farmer.  BUT they are one of the only restaurants that actually updates their website with the days menu - so check before and make sure you like the dish selections for the day.

Ambiance :  A.  Great vibe, wood burning oven, brick walls, very neighborhoody but also fit for a special occasion.  Impeccable service.
Food :  A.

Hummus and Za'taar :  The hummus is good - but nothing to write home about.  The home-made pita with za'taar on the other hand is FABULOUS - served fresh out of the oven, hot to the touch and soft as can be.  We ordered extra.

Heirloom Tomatoes:  Delicious.  Pesto was a nice touch, but you can't really screw up September heirloom tomatoes.

Pork Meatballs :  Great.  Tied with Buretta for my favorite meatball tapas.

Eggplant and Peppers:  Best dish of the night.  The subtle umami flavor of the eggplants mixed with the sweet grilled yellow peppers was heaven.  I hope they have this dish again!

Moroccan Chicken :  Although we were stuffed we loved the way the chicken just fell of the bone and the pistachio and currant broth gave a truly unique flavor that I found myself liking the plate clean.  

I can't wait to go back to see what other amazing dishes they have.
author: Casey M.

description:
WOW, this place was amazing! the staff where a delight and the food was fantastic! however, if your a big eater dont think that your going to eat dine your way into a great deal. your going to spend as much here as you would any other place. I took 3 plates to fill me up, but boy oh boy was i a happy boy! 
I had that Niman Ranch roast beef, the horseradish salsa totaly set it off, the beef was perfectly cooked, and yeah.... great! The Sea Bass was pritty good. 
After understanding just how great this place is, i have to go back and eat everything, haha
author: David P.

description:
Terzo...

Looks great.
Good Service.
Wine choices are solid.
Food....of 5 orders, 3 of them were unbearably salty. I could feel my body absorbing all the water in the air. Scary. So the food has something to be desired.

Scene - Marina. Lots of pretty girl groups.

Overall - I will go back because I like the look, wine, and service. I will not plan to have a complete meal there.
author: Sonny Y.

description:
I've been to Terzo a few times and have never been disappointed.  It has a sleek look and a hip yet cozy appeal. I find that it is easier to get a table without a reservation earlier in the evening (like when it just opens) or if all else fails, grabbing a seat at the bar makes for a lovely yet interesting meal. 

I love the Sea Bass mainly for the garbanzo beans. They taste like little balls of olive oil. So good! and the Skirt Steak is like butter (but doesn't have any on it).  

The light bulbs over the tables give off a warm glow and when the weather warrants it, they light up the  fire place which transforms the restaurant into a mini vacation. 

The servers are very knowledgeable and are not overbearing. They give informed suggestions on food and wine pairings which I love. I know my wine (enough) but always ask for recommendations because lets face it, even two Pinot Grigios from the same vintage and region are going to be vastly different and unique. 

I think this place is great. Even their staff is good looking. Who can beat that? Good food AND eye candy??? Get real!
author: J R.

description:
One, the food will make you feel good, as well as tasting delish. All locally grown and cooked with love.
Two, the service is on the mark.
Three, they have valet, but you can always catch a cab right outside.

I love taking people from out of town here.
author: L T.

description:
4.5 stars

We dined here because we could get a reservation last-minute on a Saturday and the yelpers all seemed to be digging it.

Small plates, good wines, and surprisingly easy to get a table. It's a pretty large restaurant, so they can accommodate quite a crowd.
We enjoyed a fantastic beet dish, baby artichokes, baked lingcod, and a housemade pasta with tarragon and marscapone. Everything was top-notch, especially the fish and the beets. We're pretty picky about our food and everything was up to our snobbish standards.

Wines were pretty obscure/interesting. Since I was kind of lost, the server offered me tastes of various options before I selected the glass I was having. That's a really nice touch, especially when you're spending $10 on a glass of wine. I wound up getting something I really liked and would never have found otherwise.

Portion sizes for the veggie small plates was pretty big actually. Protein portions were more in keeping with the "small plates" concept.

Overall, everything was really delicious and there were a few surprising flavors (nice - not strange or too experimental). I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a new wine experience and some tasty food at decent prices.
author: Al M.

description: I was pleasantly surprised!  The ambiance was warm and friendly, intimate and lovely.  The food was out of this world, prepared beautifully, wonderful textures and flavors, totally fresh.  Excellent service, not overbearing, helpful and the waiter chose a wonderful wine, as well.
author: Victorine M.

description:
I have never had a bad meal here.  Although the small plates add up, the food is consistently good in a nice, dressy casual environment.  Menu changes frequently but they always have the hummus which is serioulsy the best I've ever had.

Delicious!  I would spend money here any day!
author: Wendi R.

description:
Yummy deliciousness.

I went there on a Tuesday night and it was very quiet and mellow, perfect for a Tuesday night dinner.

The service was wonderful, we had a very helpful server who recommended a great wine and all of our small & large plates were delicious. I especially liked the chicken & the fava bean crostini... SOOO good.

Definitely would visit again :)
author: Danielle A.

description: Food arrived promptly and was well prepared.  Service was excellent.  The chicken was a little overcooked, skirt steak was great.  Organic plum sorbetto was very good.  Good variety of small plates and large plates.
author: Khurram Q.

description: Rounds up from 4.5 to 5 stars. My first time to Terzo, went with my wife for my birthday dinner. We wanted a romantic ambiance restaurant that was modern looking. Terzo was the perfect choice for us. The food we ordered were the small plates - arugula salad (Excellent), tomato soup (also excellent), chicken spiedini (excellent, chicken was very tender), calamari (good), and penne (very good taste, although penne not cooked enough). Would definitely recommend friends to go there.... but probably not a good restaurant for families with small kids as the tables are rather tight together and the lighting was low. Bathroom was very clean! Which to me is important.
author: Jason M.

description:
Lamb shoulder & calamari was great.
The service and ambiance really good.
Good wine selection.
Not too loud.
Could turn down the music a bit.
Overall good deal.
Would definitely go back.
author: Kaan E.

description: The atmosphere was very inviting and the food was tasty.  A little heavy on the olive oil, but hey, I can't complain because it IS a Mediterranean restaurant.  I am ready to go back and try it again!
author: Carolyn D.

description: Been here once before and had a great meal. Decided to come back again recently since it's in our neighborhood. Enjoyed another great meal (especially the calamari and mushroom small plates)... until the very end. My hubby and I aren't the kind to linger at the table once we've paid the bill, but we were engaged in conversation while I finished the last of our bottle of wine. I was pretty taken aback when the hostess came over and asked us if we had used the valet service so she could call for our car (which we didn't -- we walked to the restaurant). I guess that was her way of asking us to hit the road?? I understand there are other reservations, but it would have been nice if that was explained to us or if we were offered a seat at the bar or something. I'd recommend Terzo for the food, wine selection and ambiance -- just be sure to leave as soon as you've paid and free up your table for another patron! ;-)
author: Lekili A.

description:
Terzo exceeded all of our expectations. It was a lovely setting- modern and chic without having that industrial vibe. Service was wonderful- very helpful without being intrusive. 

One thing to note- the chef changes the menu every day, so check on the day you have your reservation to make sure what you want is there. I was a tiny bit disappointed on my 2nd visit not to have the amazing choices I had the 1st time, but the experience was still incredible.

And the food...wow. We were a group of 4 and ordered 4 small plates (server had recommended 3-4 small plates per person + a couple of big plates, but we ordered perfectly). Hummus with housemade pita, an amazing bruschetta with a fried egg, fried (greek) Haloumi cheese and roasted morels w/ asparagus. Each one better than the next. For the big plates, we ordered the salmon (a tiny bit overcooked but good) & the Greek-style chicken. Chicken was fall-off-the-bone tender, but only a thigh/leg combo...not much to share for $20. DO NOT miss the crispy onion side! 

Desserts: ice cream, flourless chocolate cake (heavenly) & pot de creme. Good God.
author: Dee B.

description: One of my go-to's for great food in the Marina with last minute reservations often available.  Good wine.  Love this place.
author: Dave G.

description: Went to Tezo the other night and took advantage of their 1/2 bottle of wine deal. It is awesome! Without the deal the bill definitely stacks up quickly. Some of the portions are small, but the food is always good
author: Annie G.

description: This place has exceptional service, an awesome wine list, which the servers are very familiar with, and the ambiance is superb.  It's romantic but not overtly made just for couples looking to get engaged.  It's more of a relaxed environment.  The menu changes so I can't say what to try next time you're there, but honestly, you can't go wrong with any of their menu items.  Try it for yourself, I guarantee you'll love it.
author: ellainne v.

description: very intricate taste, excellent execution from the chef.  Excellent for these evening when i feel like an epicurean foodie.
author: Damien J.

description:
I went here for the first time with my gal pal and we were very happy to learn upon arrival about the 1/2 price bottles of wine! The roasted beet salad with Greek yogurt was probably my favorite. Would never think to try that combo, usually see beet salad with some type of cheese so this put a creative and surprisingly delish spin to it. The mushroom and polenta dish was rich and satisfying. The hummus was predictable but still good. 
I thought the table were placed a wee bit too close together for my liking. It's one thing to choose to sit at a communal table but to have the table next to you eavesdropping to not only your conversation but the people on the other side of you is a different story. The service was warm and friendly though. The other thing I thought was a bit weird was that they have a 4 plate minimum for dinner which forced us to choose another plate even though we weren't hungry anymore. All in all I would go back, it's still a cute nighborhood gem.
author: Sara D.

description:
I love the decoration and  feel of this place. They always play great songs too.

The food changes on every day basis, which is great because every time I come to eat there, there is always something new. So you cannot ever get tired of this place.

The dishes are prepared from the best ingredients; you can tell. The chef, Mark Gordon, simply knows what he is doing.

The wine list is extensive but all I`ve tried there has simply been delicious. A huge selection of European wines makes it a bit tougher to choose from because I'm not as familiar with them as with their Californian counterparts; yet, if you dont know, just ask the servers, they're very knowledgeable and recommend a good fit for you.

As far as the service goes, the servers are all knowledgeable of the food and wine; however, I prefer to be waited on by waitresses rather than the waiters, who are sometimes too pushy.

I've gone to this place several times since it's in my neighborhood and it's been always a pleasant experience.
author: Leona B.

description: Did the best rendition of tortilla de patata outside of the Termibus station in Bilbao. I'll give it 4 stars just for that. A little pricey if your wallets running on fumes...but if you got a 9 spot you can surp on a nice little Albarino. Another 9 bucks and you'll get some Pimientos del Padron lightly fried in olive oil and sprinkled with some fleur de sel. Not bad....not bad my man.
author: Sam S.

description:
the BEST DINNER we have had in a restaurant in a long long time. the food was absolutely amazingly delicious. every bite was tasty. from appetizers, salad, main course and desert was to die for. HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS RESTAURANT!
atmosphere and people who worked there were friendly and wonderful. i give it a 10!
(not as Mediterranean as i thought it was going to be)  just so tasty
author: S. T. E.

description: The food was fine, but there are 20 restaurants within a ten minute walk of Terzo with equally fine food.  What was unbelievably sloppy and rude was the service.  The waitress was clueless and would just shout over our conversation if she came to the table in mid conversation. When we told the bus boy we wanted to order, we saw him tell our waitress and she then walked the other way. The clincher however was when we had nearly finished our dinner and the host came over and told us he really needed our table, unbelievably rude!  All of us live in the neighborhood and will never go back.  I tried this restaurant when it first opened and had a bad experience but was willing to give it another shot - what a mistake.
author: H G.

description: Wonderful wonderful food, every plate was creative and delicious. The staff were very attentive and knowledgeable. Highly recommended.
author: Dermot C.

description: Great service, sophisticated yet very comfortable ambiance, superb food, fabulous wine list, and overall excellent experience.  What a wonderful restaurant! (Note: Went with the husband and ordered 4 small plates - this was plenty of food for the two of us and not too expensive either).
author: Brooke S.

description: Love this place! Wonderful Tapas and a great atmosphere. After my first visit, I went back here a year after. I had the same waiter and he remembered me. I was shocked! Love that kind of service and hospitality. Highly recommend you try this place. Good for a date or even a small group of people.
author: Alexandra B.

description: I had dinner with my parents and my boy for my birthday at Terzo tonight. I thought about only giving 4 stars but on second thought, the food was absolutely great and exciting (it helps that they change their menu nightly), the wine list was extensive and had a good selection and price range, the staff was friendly and efficient and my whole family left the place very appeased and happy... I believe that means 5 out of 5!  I would go back there.  Reservations are a good idea, the place filled up fast! Take some friends, get a bottle of Spanish wine, order one of everything and taste some wonderful food in a beautiful setting.  Happy birthday to me!
author: Nilu r.

description: Love Terzo. Small plates are good for dates, and though the menu changes, I've never sampled something I didn't enjoy. I'm particularly in love with the sea bass and the mussels, and the beet salad.  Mmm.   More importantly (for me anyway) the people at Terzo are attentive and warm. Like Cheers, with less sarcasm.
author: Amanda B.

description:
One of my best friends was in visiting from Chicago and offered to take me out to dinner for my birthday (who is going to say no to that).  She had come up with Terzo from a Zagat guid and so we decided to go give it a chance.

I think it was love at first site - the chic yet comfy decor, impressive menu and wine list.  The two of 4 small dishes (Eggplant w/feta chilies and pomegranate - amazing!!!, Chanterelle Mushrooms done just right in a light touch of creme fraiche over a polenta that I couldn't stop eating!.  Artichoke and Fontina Frittata that melts in your mouth, and small order of the Penne Rigate with Braised Leeks, Fennel, Cream & Truffle Pecorino) perfect for the 2 of us. We also took advantage of the Sunday -Thursday 1/2 price any bottle of wine $40 or less and enjoyed a nice Cabernet-Merlot, Grand Sigognac, Medoc that paired nicely with the food.

The service was excellent, knowlegable and fun!  This place will now be a regular "go to" for me!
author: julie f.

description:
Taking a co-workers recommendation, I went to Terzo last night. I was looking for a place in the Marina that had great food, good atmosphere and that doesn't gently kick you out after you have been there for X period of time.

A great thing about Terzo is that while in the Marina, the crowd isn't typical and since it's a bit away from Fillmore, the area is bit quiter. There were people of all ages there, wearing everything from jeans to suits, who simply wanted a good meal. 

The weather was gorgeous, so we sat outside. Our server was very attentive and we had the hummus, broccoli rabini, halibut and plenty of wine. Delicious. It got a bit cold, so we moved inside to the bar where you can order drinks and food. Terzo serves small plates, so if you like trying several different things, or want a light meal - this is the place. They also have a pretty good wine list, with many American and European options. 

Everyone to the hostess to the food runners were friendly and funny and I will definitely be back.
author: Rachelle P.

description: I so wish there were more places like this in the Marina. I never hang in the area, mostly because I'm not into the "never-left-college" vibe. Anyway, Terzo is great. Small plates, small space. We had an awsome waiter, Keven. He suggested the Asparagus with house cured Tesa and the roasted Oyster Mushrooms. Both of which I would head back for. We also had the Halibut with Garbanzo beans. So much flavor in each dish it was amazing. Another selling point is that they are open late on weekends. DO make reservations and expect to wait.
author: dava g.

description: Terzo is a terrific new restaurant (April 2006) from the folks behind the also excellent Rose Pistola and Rose's cafe. The space formerly housed the very popular Pane e Vino, now at the other end of Union. It's be fantastically reborn under up and coming local architect, Cass Calder Smith. There are a variety of  seating options including at the bar and a large, communcal table and I'm told, if the rain ever stops, sidewalk and garden seating as well. The service met the high expectations set by Rose and Rose's, even on the first weekend with no practice runs. And the small plates by chef Mark Gordon are excellent. However, as with most small plate restaurants, you never feel like you're getting great value. Plates run $8-15 and the staff recommends up to 4 per person! But the wines are priced in moderation and the list is good, if light on California.
author: Patrick B.

description: The dinner was amazing, wine was phenomenal and our waiter was super friendly and knowledgeable about the menu!  I think my favourite item on the menu was the octopus, but I went back only to find out that the menu changes daily. Bummer! Even though the menu was incredible, the price seemed exorbitant.  We spent $200 for two people... which wouldn't be so bad except that the atmosphere is extremely casual and homey.  You just don't expect to empty your wallet when some guests are sitting on stools in a place that feels like your living room.
author: Zoe K.

description: My new favorite restaurant.  It's so good, I'm willing to fork over another $60 for a babysitter.  I've been to Terzo twice for a total of 11 small plates.  I would say that 10 of the 11 were mind blowing amazing.  And the 11th was just 'very good."  For a non-red meat and non-seafood eater, there were options galore.  The beet salad is the best I've ever had and was surprisingly filling.  They're constantly updating their menu and always manage to improve upon it each time, which is no small task considering that it's always an excellent dining experience.  The service is topnotch.  Unlike other small plates places, they course out the service so you're working lightest to heaviest and the meal isn't over in 20 minutes amongst a flurry of plates arriving at the same time.  The ambiance is fantastic too, with their fireplace making it smell and feel like Christmas all the time.
author: Mrsdubyah W.

description:
great fun for groups & the food is tasty, but....

$12 for an average size sausage to be split among four people is, shall we say...

er, difficult to swallow?

2.5 stars
author: Josie M.

description:
ps Open til midnight on Fri and Sat!!  Tell your friends. :)

Gorgeous space and cool layout... Totally sleek but warm and cozy too.  Nothing like Pane e Vino thank god.  

They have a separate enoteca-type menu of super small plates from "the case".  We got two crostinis.. One with w/ favas and mint (delicious!) and one w/ hard-boiled egg and anchovy (egg yolk barrely cooked yum).  Nice to start with.

Then my friend insisted we get the roasted marrowbones, which she said were really awesome.  My other friend and I gave it a shot, but honestly, pushing out jiggly transluscent fatty blobs with organ-looking strands in the middle just didn't do it for me.  I still have the creeps just thinking about it...

Anyway.  The halibut with garbanzos and romesco was all of our favorite.  Great flavor, super tasty.  Arugula salad was so fresh and hearty actually served with pine nuts & pecorino.  Tuna crudo toasts were lip-smacking.  Asparagus & house-cured ham was smoky and satisfien.  Next time I want to try the Morroccan pea soup and  roasted oyster mushies.  And actually, the slabs of super rare roasted beef laid on rosemary potatoes looked pretty darn good too.

Great Soave white for $44 a bottle.  Great all-around.  YUM.
author: Melanie C.

description:
Food was Fabulous - esp. for tapas...homemade pita...mm mm...not even my parents can make it that good! 

I was particularly impressed with the roasted beets with yogurt dish. Great staff, esp. the GM. 

I really liked the ambiance, as well...romantic - very nice place in the hussle bussle of the marina...
author: sarah e.

description: Last night I had dinner at Terzo with two of my good girlfriends. The decor is beautiful--modern, but still homey at the same time--not at all reminiscent of the old Pane E Vino. The food was delicious, I especially liked the Fennel a la Grecque, and Roasted Oyster Mushrooms, as well as the Gnocchi. Our waiter was extremely nice and our food arrived promptly. We were able to hang out and drink wine without feeling rushed. I recommend this for a night out with friends or a romantic date.
author: michaela w.

description: I wasn't sure what to expect here and didn't have high expectation but this little pace is great. The atmosphere was great and the place just looks cool. Our waiter was very friendly and gave us great advice on both wine and dinner. Figs were fantastic as were the fried green tomatoes. We had a bunch of different things and each one was delicious. We'll be back soon!
author: Kelly C.

description:
This is my first review on Yelp, which I've just joined. This restaurant served as the catalyst. Making the list of SF Gate's Top 100 Restrauants, I expected a good meal for two for around $100. What I got was a bad meal and bad service, with the only thing surpassing my expectations being the $130 bill. And yes, I "get" the whole tapas, small plates genre - that's not my quarrel. My specific complaints are as follows (I've even shortened them substantially): 

House Cured Meats: for about $15 you get 6 slices of salami, the amount & quality of which you can find on an average slice of pizza. I'm Italian, live in North Beach, & spent a year living in Rome. Please just give me the benefit of the doubt on this one.
Bad Service: Wobbly table, smack in the middle of two other tables - when "cozy with your fellow diners" crosses into "get your bad breath away from me" territory.  At the end of the meal, we were given the WRONG check; upon kindly informing our Server, she tried to tell us otherwise! When she realized her error, a curt response of "oh yeah" was all she could muster.  The last police officer who gave me a speeding ticket was more apologetic AND deserving of a tip.
Overpriced: My $250 two-person meal at Farallon was like the Louisiana Purchase in comparison, making my meal at Terzo akin to buying stock in Bear Stearns. It's not that the meal was worthless, but at $60 (not $130) I felt like buyer & seller both could have left the deal satisfied.

The one good thing about Terzo is that it directly lead to my participation in Yelp.  One star, thanks to the wine. 2004 red portugal & 2005 Saint Josephs red.
author: Donald R.

description:
A new Marina favorite, Terzo gets most things right.  The sea bass and mushroom bruchetta were the biggest hits.  I was not impressed with the hommus because it lacks flavor but the Zatar ftat bread that accompanies it is pretty tastey.

You can't leave without having the flourless chocolate cake.

The biggest miss, which is actually pretty big for a "small plates" restaurant, is that none of the dishes are presented in a way that makes sharing easy.
author: Maria R.

description: Great little place. We stuck with the small plates, which is the way to go if you want to sample a bunch of tasty dishes. My date and I ordered four or five and that was plenty. My fav? The grilled shiitake and polenta.... awesome. Service was great too. Only downside was that the music was too loud where we were sitting.
author: Gannon H.

description: This is a great place.  I see all the mentions of 'small plates' which I don't think are totally fair - yes they are not the huge plates you see other places, but they are meal-sized.  And I would call it more Mediterranean than Greek, but very good nonetheless.  The dishes are original, fresh, and fresh takes on classics.  I had brussel sprouts with an Iowa Pork Chop (how could you not like that) all cooked perfectly.  And they should be praised for their wine list - interesting, broad, and for the most part reasonable.  The place has a good 'neighborhood bistro but nice' vibe; I could see where it could be either intimate or fun - or both...  One of my new 'go-to' places in The City, highly recommended.
author: Arthur S.

description: I have been coming here for quite a while now (I think about 4 or 5 years). A couple of my friends and I have even deemed it to be "our date spot" for when the three of us need to catch up.  I started coming here because my friend worked behind the bar, but he has since moved to NYC and I still keep coming back.  I like to skip the larger plates, although they are usually pretty awesome, and focus on sharing the rest of the menu.  I always get the Hummus, panzarotto (calzone type pastry) and chicken spiedini.  The menu changes all the time but these favorites are always there for me.  The wine list is great and sometimes they have deals on bottles, but more then anything it is a cozy place that has not disappointed me in the over 20 times I have visited.  Oh yeah the service is almost always on point
author: Young J.

description: This isn't the absolute best place, but I must say that the 50% off bottles of wine (under $40) paired with the company and the tapas, it wasn't too bad.  I enjoyed the atmosphere.  The staff was extremely nice and provided great opinions on the wine and food.  The portions ARE SMALL, so if you're going to go with a big crowd, be ready to order a lot in order to fill up.
author: Carmen C.

description: The food is pretty good but the reason I go there, and anyone should go there is the hostess Kira, not only is she friendly and personable, she makes the entire dining experience more enjoyable and worth while.
author: Thomas E.

description: Many of the dishes are actually excellent (eg: the halibut on garbanzo beans and the meatballs, which are currently off the menu but may return - yum) but felt the service and the value were lacking.  Small plates format in this price range should provide serving utensils, fresh plates.
author: Laurie A.

description: Food is delicious, nice, intimate atmosphere, friendly and smart staff. Small plates are great to share...nice date spot!
author: Sarah C.

description: Nothing really to complain about, I just don't see what all the hype is. Lovely surroundings, approachable wine list, pretty food but kind of bland.  Glad I tried it but not itching ot go back.
author: e w.

description:
atmosphere: 5 stars. great place to go on a date. makes you feel like you are on vacation (maybe wine country).

service: below average. it was weird how so many different people brought our food, cleared our table, brought the bill, etc.

food: overall was food was good, but very greasy (they used a lot of olive oil). the hummus was good minus the pool of olive oil that was in the middle. the fava bean bruschetta was delicious, definitely one of the highlights of them meal (it almost tasted like hummus on bread, do not expect tomatoes on this bruschetta). the chicken spiedini was also excellent, i loved the cilantro in it. finally we ordered the panzarotto & marinara, which was like a calzone, it was OK, I've had better (that's what she said).

4 small plates for 3 people = $20/each. It was enough food for us, but we don't really eat that much. We also didn't get wine, long story (bottom line one of us, who is 24 forgot her ID & they wouldn't serve her, so we decided not to order any wine).

I would go back for the atmosphere & wine, could have been an off night & the menu is always changing so I would definitely give it another try.
author: Elaine S.

description: There's not much more I can say about this place that hasn't already been said except go check it out for yourself. The food is tapes style and is amazing. It's good to go with a small group of friends so that you can try everything on the menu. I have been eating here almost weekly since they opened. The food is awesome and the staff is exceptionally friendly. I take that back, their not just friendly their family. The decor is warm, inviting and modern without being over the top. The atmosphere is upscale but relaxed and comfortable without formality and pretension. Don't be too surprised to find Executive Chef Mark Gordon stopping by your table to see how you are. There is such a good vibe to this place that goes beyond capturing in print. It's something you just have to experience for yourself!
author: Tim S.

description:
i met my friend for dinner here last night, and it was not bad.  we were able to walk in on a wed night around 8 pm and get a table w/ no problems.  from the outside, the restaurant looks small, but it opens up to a fairly big room, and there are many tables in the back room.

between the two of us, we shared the hummus, grilled sea bass, autumn chantarelles w/ polenta, and roasted sweet potatoes.  the hummus was good, but the pita bread that came w/ it was even better.  it was piping hot w/ herbs on top, which made it delish.  the sea bass atop chickpeas were great as well, and so were the chantarelles.  the roasted sweet potatoes were good but not that exciting.  for dessert, we shared a glass of portuguese port and the ginger cake w/ all spice ice cream.  we also each had a glass of wine, and i had a coffee, and it was about $90 before tax and tip.

the portions here are fairly small, so i thought it was a bit pricey, but the ambience is nice, and they played good, loungy music in the background.
author: Helen T.

description: Great decor, good service, and fantastic food. Make sure to order the pita & hummus!
author: Sean F.

description: I've been wanting to try this place for a while but was hesitant because of the spendy menu but on Saturday I bucked up and went with a close friend. We were delighted with the atmosphere and actually sat at a community table with a few other folks which I surprisingly didn't mind. We ordered a (fully cooked) tuna and english pea salad which had amazing flavor and was light and fresh! Then we each ordered the skirt steak which was very flavorful and pretty tender though the portion was fairly small and the green beans were a little soggy (but flavorful). Next came dessert and we ordered a chocolate "cake", which was ok but not exciting. The wine list was good but I did feel like our waitress was not well informed on the wine's and their pairings. With tip and bill we each paid $60!
author: Nikki W.

description: I thought it was a lovely meal.  Everything tasted fresh and well prepared.  Had the fig salad, the beets, the flatbread, the seabass and the pluot tart...not a single complaint about any of them.  Actually I usually don't love non-Asian preparations of fish but the seabass with the garbanzo beans was to die for.  Yes a very lovely meal.  Oh, the cousin pointed out that it was nice to have a full page wine by the glass selection.
author: Jen C.

description: This is a tough one. The food is great - high quality and well prepared. The wait staff is super attentive (even when my friend smashed her wine glass after placing it too hard on the table to make a point). But really, we shared about 3 inches of seabass for $14 and three slices of really tasty beef for about the same price. The cheapest decent wine (aside from some portuguese stuff), was $39. So basically it was $50 a head for a few nibbles and really nice wine. The crowd was mostly girls catching-up, which makes sense. We don't eat much. Come here with a guy and it would be way more expensive.  Oh, and some potatoes would be great. Even girls can't live on beets and hummus. That said the atmosphere and music was nice. I'm torn. Kind of like going on a great date with a married guy :-)
author: jane t.

description: Love the sharing of small plates, and family style tables . . . Our favorite waiter of all time always greets with a smile, and fabulous service . . .
author: BJ D.

description:
A recipe for a terrible evening deconstructed:

Step 1.  Simmer guests nerves by making them wait 20 minutes standing between a table of two women gossiping about floral arrangements, and the intense cougar on mougar (man cougar) action at the bar.  Continue to saute an additional 5 minutes even though the table is ready.
Step 2.  Fold in horrible waiter who 1) keeps pushing guests to order more drinks, 2) recites nearly the entire menu as his favorites (especially the beef, which the adjacent table had sent back) and 3) asserts that the dishes came out in normal time (although dishes 1 & 2 came 20 minutes before 3 & 4), but profusely apologizes once the check looms near.
Step 3.  Bring out the bland entrees in the following order: salmon (decent), chicken skewers (decent).  Wait another 20 minutes to the point where even the waiter asks if guests are ready for the check.  Then bring out sausage (above average).  End with a huge plate of onion rings (needed sauce).  Mmmm onion breath is totally hot!!!

SF Chronicle's Top Ten of 2006 ladies and gentleman?  I think not.  Not worth your time or your money.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Here's another restaurant I used to work at,  (Thank God I have a REAL job now) and man I gotta say I made some serious coin working here tipwise...Too bad management treated us like shit! However to be fair, I gotta hand it to the little half-midget head cook Mark Gordon that he can cook.  Great food and really amazing decor here..if you cant get in a girls pants after taking a chick here, man you got serious problems...and any chick that cant appreciate being taken to an expensive place like this has no sense of appreciation  and chances are if you stay with her long term, you'll probably spend every ounce of energy you can muster attempting to meet her unrealistic expectations anyway. SO GIVE HER THE "TERZO TEST"! Just statin the obvious folks. I tell the truth here, even if it aint popular..youre getting the truth from me! You always will.

The management is actually really good at hiring good help (Shit, they hired me at one time didnt they?) so the service is tip top. I dont drink anymore but when I did I loved their wine list...they used to serve a Fort Ross Pinotage that was out of this world...talk about a really BIG red..complex too

the space has a real dark ambiance, yet very warm....truly the perfect place to take a chick you're just dying to get in the sack...I would have to say its a sexy place...check it out!
author: jes s.

description: our third time there, the food was as excellent as ever and the service better than last time, but...we called for reservations and were told 45 minutes. arriving 15 minutes later, we were told 45 minutes. what happened between then and then? apparently we didn't talk to the right person. um, ok. we'll go back, but hopefully the hostess won't.
author: David D.

description:
i've always wondered about this place, but thought it was a 'fancy' place until my cousins finally suggested we go the other night. i figured why not, and was pleasantly surprised. 

aside from the fact that it's pretty close to my place, it's actually not as fancy as i had suspected, and it's much bigger inside than i expected, but still quaint and cozy with a working fireplace, perfect for these cold winter nights. 

i got there a bit early, and after discussing it with the server, orderd a glass of wine she suggested. not really what i was looking for, she offered to bring me something else, but i was fine with what she had brought, i didn't want to be a bother. 

when my cousins arrived, we decided to do a selection of their small plates and 2 of the large plates (there was 5 of us). the hummus was good, but i think there are better things worth ordering. the egg bruschetta was yummy, something i'd definitely get again. the egg was gently cooked and when cut into it the yolk was beautifully runny. the chicken spiedini was really good too, although on the first try, the chicken was very undercooked, but they quickly remedied that. their version of a calzone was popular among my cousins, but i wasn't a huge fan, i felt it to be a bit bland...we also ordered the mushrooms with polenta, but i thought it was only okay. 

we had the spaghetti with pistachio pesto and skirt steak as our main plates, along with a side order of the crispy onions. i thought the spaghetti was also a bit bland but the steak was amazing, and crispy onions were a perfect pairing. i'll definitely want to come back and check it out again....
author: Angela W.

description: Great service, great meal. Got sick later that night, not sure it was Terzos fault, but it was good going down, The beets (yeah beets) were tasty, the tomato torte was outstanding, the mussels were good (but a bit modest on the portion) A good looking dining room with a nice wine list -- the sancerre is good and the rose was great.
author: Sean G.

description: It is a little pricey for the portions, but all of the 6 or so dishes we tried were quite tasty.  i was especially a fan of the broccoli (or was is broclini?).  The chocolate cake was damn good, as were the wine recommendations.
author: Robert R.

description:
Update: 

I originally rated this at 5 stars. Time for a major bump-down. Yes, the food was still fantastic the last time I was there, BUT they made a major, huge restaurant no-no, in my book: 

We had reservations for 7 pm. We got there at 10 'til. They had us sit in the bar area while we waited... and waited.... and waited..... for 50 minutes - that's 40 minutes past our original reservation time. Just to add insult to injury, the only time the host or hostess came by was to give us a wan, obsequious smile and shoulder-shrug that said  "Ooops... Sorry... looks like it's going to be a 'little' bit longer." We got lame excuses about people taking too long to pay their check and clear out (not my business, not my problem), that it would only be a few more minutes (total B.S.), etc, and NOBODY offered to hook us up with something to nosh on in the meantime, like a free app or something on the house (HELLO - we're friggin' HUNGRY here... we had planned on eating by now... If we hadn't have planned on it, we would have eaten something before we left the house). Lame, lame lame lame lame lame. 

Look, we were a two-top for cripes sake. If you can't figure out how to seat a deuce within 20 minutes of the reservation time, it's time to fire the hosts & hostesses and consider a different seating layout of your restaurant. Or, better yet, just stop taking reservations. What's the point of offering this service if you can't honor it? 

The experience was inexcusable, especially for mid-week. I DID love the food here, but I will be very hard-pressed to go back. It's just not worth the roullette of "will I get seated before I pass out from sugar-low or not?"

--- ORIGINAL REVIEW --- 5 stars

Mark Gordon's latest endeavor is another big win. If you're familiar with Rose's Cafe, which is across the street from Terzo, then you already know the beauty of Mark's fresh produce selection and his talent for delicately balancing traditional flavors with fresh concepts. 

The menu is concieved around small plates that are meant to be shared at the table, not unlike tapas, but without the straight up spanish influence. Terzo's dishes are pan-european, I'd say, in their offering... ranging from a mediterranean chicken skewer dish to a fresh mozzarella / heirloom tomato salad offering. 

The real trick to this food is how fresh everything is. I cannot emphasize this enough. Gordon's focus on quality is evident in his selection of local vegetable purveyors... on our first night at Terzo, we tried the mozzarella / heirloom tomato salad, which all in all, given how commonly this dish appears on restaurant menus, would be difficult to elevate to a "supreme" level... yet, that's exactly what happened. 

My husband and I cut into the dish and took our first taste and were immediately awash in the simple beauty of the salad's blend of perfect olive oil dancing with either a grey salt or a sea salt and the explosion of the tomatos counterbalanced by the mellowness of the mozzarella that combined to a perfect bite. These "perfect bites" are rare, where everything presents in a single moment as a piqued, balanced and varied gastronomic extravaganza, almost a complete meal's-worth of flavors and textures in a single mouthful that my husband refers to as the "kevane bite." Dee licious. 

After this one mouthful, I looked at my husband, stunned, and said, "There is something seriously wrong with this world where we can stroll into a restaurant on a Saturday night in a world-class city like SF without reservations and have such perfect food." Granted, we had come in at 11 PM (in keeping with the tapas ethos, Gordon has kept the hours more european at Terzo, allowing for the later-evening crowd to wander in), and San Francisco does tend to roll up its sidewalks early, but if this restaurant were in NY, even at 11 there would have been a line out the door.
author: Hannah Q.

description: The vegetarian small plates on the menu were pretty unimpressive and a little bland.  When my friend asked for some sort of hot sauce to spice up our food, we were told  by a waitress "we don't do sauces."  It was so absurd that the guys sitting  at the table next to us commented on it.  On the plus side, our waiter was super-- fun and friendly and enthusiastic-- and helped us pick out a bottle of great white wine.
author: shoba d.

description:
There's been some changes at Terzo since my last visit.  They've made the portions more substantial and upped the prices a bit, but overall the experience is still satisfying.

Food:  3 stars.   The menu is now divided between an assortment of small plates and 4-5 larger plates, along with two sides.  Some items were spot on, while others left me perplexed.  Of the small plates, I thoroughly enjoyed the hummus plate, the goat skewers and the free range chicken spiedini.  The baked goat cheese was decent, but there was not enough toasted baguette slices in proportion to the cheese and fig preserves.  For the larger plates, we had the grilled coho salmon, grilled organic pork chop, and grilled niman ranch skirt steak.  The juicy pork chop, served with spatzle, roasted turnips and apple compote, was my fave.  The skirt steak, served with roasted potatoes, radicchio, and salsa verde, was an average dish and not too inspiring.  I absolutely hated the salmon, which came with a over-charred skin.  I enjoyed the garbanzo beans that it came with more than the ashy flavor of the salmon itself.  The worst part about it is that the waiter said it was the last one left, so we had higher expectations for it.  We also ordered a side of crispy onions, which were decent but a bit too salty.  For dessert, we shared the chocolate pudding cake with whipped cream and scoops of sherry-prune (think rum raisin) and mint confetti ice cream.  The cake by itself was delicious, but was marred by the ice cream flavors (the mint confetti reminded me of medicine).

Service:  4 stars.   Our server was awesome.  He was super friendly, humorous, and played off of my lame jokes.  His menu recommendations (the pork chop, goat skewers, chicken spiedini) were spot on, but I really wish he didn't try to go above and beyond to get us that last salmon.

Atmosphere:  4 stars.  The place is still somewhat trendy and chic, yet warm and inviting (thanks in large part to the central fireplace).  The crowd is generally attractive and young, but sometimes a little crass (there was some inappropriate conversation at the table to our left, don't bring the kiddies!).

Hits:   Hummus, grilled pork chop.

Misses:  Coho salmon, mint confetti ice cream.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  COCO500, Cortez, Laiola
author: Keith C.

description: One of my favorite date restaurants in San Francisco.  Everything I have had here has been great. It my person al favorites are the skirt steak with chimichurri sauce and the homemade hummus.
author: Tom H.

description: This is a great place for hanging out and catching up with good friends. The atmosphere is contemporary, yet rustic. The brick and fire make it cozy, but the lighting and mirrors give it a modern-appeal. The food is EXCELLENT. I highly recommend the roaster oyster mushrooms as well as the spiendalini (not sure I spelled that right ;)). The service was great and we were free to linger and catch-up - a plus. Would go back again and again! We also enjoyed the Sobon 2004 Old Vine Zinfandel, which was an excellent and affordable wine option.
author: elizabeth s.

description: Wholly Carbs! The Humus dish is a must, chicken kabobs also, but they need to take the weird bread filler out(it just makes it look like you are getting more chicken and you may eat it on accident(carbs)). Stay away from the asparagus souffle, more carbs. Arugula salad was great and the oranges were even better. Seabass was so good but way overpriced for such a little piece and garbanzo beans meant more carbs. The mussels looked really good. Great winelist and we did indulge. Close tables but if you go early enough it is intimate. I would go back but will make sure to get in an extra long workout the next day.
author: Bryan M.

description:
this place is small and loud, imho. like an obnoxious chihuahua: all bark, no bite. no quiero terzo, mannnn...

... but i love their wine menu!

the thing is, we came here for drinks and grub about a year ago. since i imagine that they change their menu from time to time, my review probably doesn't apply, but i'll go on anyway and make a point to update later.

their food was a tad oversalted (all 5 dishes), their portions are overtiny, and also grossly overpriced considering that we left still ravenous. and way parched. not to mention the feeling of ripped offedness. don't get me wrong: we liked what we ate, but we felt that the value wasn't enough to justify the price (meal only- wine was fantastic). i was tempted to stop at 7-11 and get me a damn 42oz. slurpee and 2 taquitos for 2 bucks, since that's about all i had in my pocket besides lint and my dignity.

the pros: the wait staff and FOH were way helpful and attentive. the bartender is a heavy-handed pourer (prolly to trick your ass into ordering more salty food, then another drink... alas, the vicious circle!) and the interior is small, yet fairly quiet and smartly decorated with a yuppie flair and homey undertones, like a big beautiful floral arrangement between the dining space and the pretty shiny bar. i really admire what they did with such a small place. parking is also fairly easy and is located in a safe neighborhood. this is really important to me because once i came back from dinner somewhere in the mission only to find a bum sleeping soundly in my front seat! WTF!?? 

anyway, yeah. i'd come back. maybe if they have some sorta happy hour special or bar menu thing-- i'm not gonna commit to dinner. not just yet...
author: Vanessa D.

description: Terzo was all right, but not good enough for a return visit.  The service is excellent, but the food is so-so...  And I'm all about the food.
author: Tina T.

description: I love the ambiance in this place. They did a nice job with the design. I also liked that the menu changes every night.  The food was good, but not great. If youre looking for something a little more snazzy than the casual places in the Marina, this is not a bad option.
author: Alden H.

description: The food is very good,but the portions are so skimpy that I left the restaurant hungry. Also $25 for corkage is excessive. The service was spotty.
author: Barry G.

description: Wine list was great. Had a table at the front by the window, pretty much secluded. Service was awesome! (Jessica was our server.) Food was wonderful, as we just kind of snacked on a few appetizers and then the pumpkin tirramisu  was amazing! Loved the fireplaces!
author: Courtney M.

description: One of my favorite places to eat in SF! The hummus and meatballs in polenta are absolutely fantastic.  Great place to go with a group of people to share small plates and great wine.
author: G A.

description: Terzo provides a cozy and warm enviornment to break bread with family or friends. They have small plates which are def on the small side but they offer generous portions with their large plates. The pork chop, beet salad, and hummus plate were my favorites. This is def a great Cow Hollow spot!
author: Cindu T.

description: The Meritage wine we had was good and the skirt steak was excellent.  We also had less memorable appetizers or what they called small plates - one was a dungeness crab and celery root remoulade with oranges that needed more crab.  I barely tasted the crab with all the celery root.  I don't think I'll come back that's why I gave it 3 stars.
author: emelito d.

description: ....I am so overdue for another visit at Terzo and pay a visit to my favorite check Mark Gordon. He is a genius! I particularly like restaurants that switch up their menu, I like the surprise effect, I prefer being offered seasonal items and knowing that they are fresh, I am excited to know I will taste new flavors I may have never experienced before, I love small plates and sharing - all this is Terzo. To tell you the truth the Marina is not my usual hang out, nor my favorite district of SF, but there are a few restaurants that are worth the trip! Terzo is one of them.
author: Judith B.

description: The sleek and cozy space pairs nicely with the tasty yet comforting small plates. The steamed clams is a must! This is the kind of place  where you just want to hang out and enjoy another glass a wine after your meal just to soak up the ambience. Soon to be a neighborhood hit!
author: Joslyn D.

description:
This new little gem in Cow Hollow has incredibly tasty small plates - so why only three stars?  Well, the service could use a bit of work, namely:  a) if you are pouring your customer a Cote du Rhone - don't pour every last drop of the bottle, there will be sediment down there which will wind up in someone's glass -- eww, gross; b) if you are serving a group of four and you know most of your small plates come in three servings, why don't you give them a heads up so they can order more accordingly; c) if you are a small plate establishment, leave one menu on the table so your customers can order more if they want.
Other than the service and not ordering enough food - the small plates were absolutely scrumptious.  Some of our faves included:  hummus, halibut, tuna and the artichoke ravioli.  I will certainly be going back to this newest local restaurant and hoping by then the kinks will be worked out.  The food is just too too good to not go back.
PS- Make a reservation no matter what night or time of the week you are dining, it always seems to have a crowd.
author: Katie P.

description:
Went to Terzo on a random Tuesday and was able to get seated immediately...it was a beautiful day so we sat outside which was a great way to enjoy the small plates. the food was good however the portions were small and somewhat pricey.  This is more of a place where I would stop by for a glass of wine and a couple of appetizers before dinner...or desserts after dinner....

The one thing that really stood out for me though was their fig and cheese dessert....I don't usually like most cheeses or figs but this was good! a great balance of sweet and savory....
author: Joy Y.

description: I had high expectations for this place, especially after reading all the reviews - but I was disappointed.  The space is great - not loud, very had a good, lively vibe.  The menu is all small plates - we split the beet salad, chicken spedini, mussels, pasta, hummus, halibut, and the figs wrapped in bacon.  The bacon was overcooked, the chicken was alright.  The hummus and the pasta were the standouts - everything else was mediocre.  The desserts we had (caramel fleur de sel tart) was delicious.  It's a fun place to go with a group, but the food was really mediocre and ended up being pricey since all those little plates add up!
author: Christina S.

description: Sexy, sleek... but may leave you hungry.  The food is truly tasty, lots to choose from, but somehow I have never left feeling completely satisfied (despite ordering and consuming nearly everything on the menu with my friends)...  Good place for drinks and small bite, not so great for real meal.
author: kristin s.

description: Continues to deliver. Great food and service. Good use of fresh/in season fruits and vegtables. A peach brushcetta? Awesome. As noted, lots of good wines by the glass, the server did not disappoint with his suggestions...
author: Jason M.

description: I'm kicking myself for not visiting Terzo before, it was probably one of the best meals I've had in San Francisco. Every plate was fresh and so delicious- but minus one star for the rude condescending waitress who kept talking down to us as if we were kids pretending to be grown-ups. Whatever lady, my money is just as good as the old people's at the next table.
author: Lucia R.

description: Terzo can't be beat if you're looking for fresh, small plates and good wine to share. A few all-time favorites include the homemade hummus and pita, beet salad and any fish they have on the menu. If you go Sun-Thurs, they offer half off bottles of wine under $40 - pretty sweet deal.
author: S.J. B.

description: The one and only in Marina LOVE everything food wine people decor service. Go there all the time. The staff is fantastic! Get the chicken, asparagus, or beets. I DIE!
author: Nickolas V.

description: Brilliant in every way. Fantastic service, fantastic food, great ambiance, great wines, cool down-tempo electronica. Only improvement area I thought: dessert.
author: mandar p.

description: Decent winelist that is inventive and risk taking, with Swiss wine and wines from little known areas of France, but the Chassalas was a bit tired and the Juracon Sec a bit bretty.  The dishes were good, with the highlight being the Bruscetta of tomatoes panchetta and fried egg.  The Calzone was extremely boring and tasted a bit like a hot pocket and the bean salad was a bit overwhelmed by the Thyme.  The Squash Carpaccio was a nice dish, but no real wow factor, and really enjoyed the Calamari, Clams and pasta dish(Favorite part was the dipping the bread in the sauce).
author: Steven S.

description: I like Terzo a lot. I live a block away so I have eaten there maybe fifteen times and always found the food always good.  I love the high group table!  The waiters are great and the wine is fantastic!  good hang place or intimate mellow night.  It i a Tapa's type place with local california food.  Yeah!
author: Cristof E.

description: Went here on Valentine's day and couldn't have had a better evening.  We were seated right away upon arriving, and althought the quarters were close, we suprisingly didn't feel cramped or crowded.  Our waitress was extrmely attentive and offered great wine and food suggestions, all of which we took and loved!  Food came quickly, although we didn't feel rushed, and I loved the way that their portions are set up so that you share....really gave us an opportunity to try multiple things on the menu.  On top of everything else, the decor was simple yet inviting and had a really modern-chic look to it.  I would definitely go back to Terzo in a heart beat.....also, it seemed like it would be a great place to go with a (moderately sized) group too.
author: Liz L.

description: LOVE, LOVE, LOVED our dinner here. From the attentive and funny server to the perfect wine he steered us towards, not to mention the delicious food. Save room for dessert. The chocolate gooey cake was so good and amazingly light that I wrote to Gourmet to see if I could get them to publish the recipe. This is a repeater for sure.
author: amy l.

description: My husband and I have been coming here since the day it opened and have NEVER been disappointed. Everyone that works there is so friendly and happy to help you. They make you feel like family when you are there especially Ron. Words are not enough to describe how delicious the food is and so consistent every time we come here. The small plates are great because you get to try everything. The ambiance is cozy and romantic. I highly recommend coming here very soon! We can't wait to come back for more!
author: Lauren F.

description:
We were visiting San Francisco from NC and picked Terzo online for their menu which was very appealing, especially the small plates. We love to try lots of different things. 

Each dish was perfectly prepared and presented. We ordered 4 small plates to share and were impressed with the way they paced the delivery of each one. The dishes came in exactly the order requested. We were not hurried through any of the selections. 

The white wine flight was also a nice way to sample several wines. Our waitress, Niccole, was especially adept at describing each wine; one could almost taste them just from her description. 

We chose the chicken spiendini, arugula salad, panzarotto & marinara and tomato braised pork meatballs. As mentioned earlier, each dish was excellent. Our particular favorite was the panzarotto, which Niccole explained was made with potato dough. It was like a calzone except the bread was delicate and more delicious. 

The ending was a simple vanilla ice cream sundae with cappuccino, a delightful and perfect finish.

We could not have been more pleased with this experience and plan to return to Terzo on our next visit to SF.
author: Cindy T.

description: Food and wine here is delicious. Mussels are some of the best I've had. Try a bottle of Quinta de Cabriz Reserva, Dao, Portugal. It's a great choice and since we were there on a Thursday night, it was half off for only $20. Now that's a real bargain! Chicken Spiedini is good, also Braised Lamb, Meatballs w/Polenta. Very good dessert list too. Just don't sit in the back room on a cold night. Main room has a fireplace and more ambiance - kind of cozy. Back room is a lot quieter (and a bit chilly) but then the background music is louder. Definitely go Sun-Thurs and save on the wine!
author: Dorothy W.

description: Sad wine list, food is so so and the service minimally accepable. Much, much better places near by to choose from.
author: Linda S.

description:
Where o where do I begin?  I guess the beginning is a good place to start.  Overall, it was a good restaurant.  

Finding the Restaurant:  It's very easy to just walk/ drive by it without noticing that it's there.  There is no visible sign, just a metal rooster hanging out front.

Parking: Everyone who hangs out in the area knows about parking.  It's hard to find.  They do offer valet parking for $10.   Sometimes, valet parking is worth it in that area if you don't want to circle the block for a long time.  By the way, I saw their Vallet guys park some of the cars in the street, so if you can find street parking, you saved $10.  

Ambiance:  It's a very cozy place.  It's cute and trendy.  The lighting is very nice.  If you can, take the back room.  You may feel like the bad kids put in the corner, but it's definitely a lot roomier than the front.  If you don't like loud music, don't sit in the back room.  The music was so loud that the staff couldn't hear us when we called them.  One of the hostesses even came by and said she'd turn down the music because it was too loud.  I did like sitting underneath the large skylight.  It made for a nice dining experience.

Staff:  The service was below par.  The table we were seated at was wobbly, and it took 20 minutes before someone bothered to help us with it.  We tried to get everyone's attention, but apparently we were invincible.  The service itself took longer than it really needed to considering it wasn't full and they had a full staff.  However, our waiter was a really nice guy and that made the service no so bad.  Heck, we even gave him a big tip.

Food:  If you are hungry, don't go here.  You'll still be starving before the meal is done.  They suggest 2 to 3 plates per person.  I'd go with three.  Food is brought to the table one dish at a time.  It kind of makes you wonder where the rest of the food is and how long it'll take to get to your table.  If you're there to talk and /or drink more than eat, then service is fine.  If you're there to eat, you'll wonder how many hours and dishes it'll take before you get full.  The food itself is delicious.  They change their menu daily except for about 4 regular dishes they keep on the menu.  By the way, if you don't like onions, you may want to tell the waiter ahead of time.  Almost everything we ordered had onions.  Here's what we ate:

Blackberry Italian Soday:  it's very refreshing and delicious
Hummus:  The pita was delicious.  The hummus was a bit too dry even though they drizzled olive oil on it.  
Porcini & Sweet Corn Salad: If you don't like fennel, you won't like this salad.  I'm a big mushroom fan, so I liked it.  It's a very light salad.
Summer Squash Salad: Get it!  It was nice and light.  I can see why it's a favorite.
Arugula Salad: It's a very simple and delicious salad.  One of my favorite kinds.
Chicken skewers:  They give 2 hearty skewers per order.  It's very tasty.  When you look at it, it seems like a lot of chicken.  Then, when you look closer, it's actually toasted spicy bread mixed with chicken.
Niman Beef: They say it's cooked medium rare, but it's more rare.  If you don't like to look at rare meat, this plate is NOT for you.  Two of the people with me couldn't even eat it.  
Flatbread:  It's very tasty.  MMM Balsamic Vingear goodness!  It's drizzled with so many herbs and nuts.  Very mediterranean.
Jamon Serrano Bruschetta:  Very hammy and very cheezy!  I loved it.  
Fried Onion Strings: Too salty, too oily, not crunchy enough.  But since I'm a sucker for onion strings, I liked it.
Dessert: go elsewhere unless you're getting the homemade ice cream.  The semolina wheat cake was like eating flavorless couscous.  The minute you bit into it, it crumbled...and not in a good way.  The strawberry and rose cream with merangue - just eat strawberries at home.  When I imagine merengue, I imagine fluffy goodness.  On this dessert, it was a small flat square.  The cream tasted like regular creme even though it's supposed to be rose cream.  The strawberries were covered with what looked like sugary syrup ( think strawberry pie).  It was good, but not worth getting again.
author: Miss T.

description:
Nothing wrong with the decor here. I liked that it felt hip but intimate, and I really dug the high, communal table. 

And nothing wrong with the food here, either. It was good. But apart from this mushroom-polenta plate we had, nothing was great.

Would I come back of my own initiative? Probably not with options like Palmetto or A16 or Mamacita around. Would I be unhappy if someone invited me there? Nope, sounds like a perfectly fine evening.
author: Midori S.

description:
One of the best "geeky" restaurant in San Francisco right now.  Every single plate of food is well executed and thought out.  Terzo is especially good when I have to eat with a vegetarian friend.  I can pretty much order all the vegetarian dishes and be satisfied as a carnivore (but I still secretly crave their delicious pork chop on those nights...).

The head chef Mark Gordon is very good at making food that's super approachable with wine. In addition, Terzo in the last couple years amassed one of the most interesting wine list in the Bay Area.  How many restaurant in the world can you get 1936 Riversalte by the glass with your desert???
author: B L.

description: Loved this place! Our server was very knowledgeable and friendly, and recommended some excellent dishes and a great bottle of wine. We had the mozzarella di bufala with olive focaccia, the mahi-mahi and penne rigate, and the gnocchi. All dishes were fantastic, and portion sizes were just right. The gnocchi, especially, was quite possibly the best I've had, and definitely redeemed all other fairly average gnocchis I've had to endure in the past. Our dessert, the flourless chocolate cake, was a great end to the meal. Will almost certainly go back here.
author: Shw S.

description: Very nice place, well designed by attentive eye.  Service professional.  Appetizers (brussel sprouts with feta, flat bread) were very good.  Entree (chicken marsala) not bad.  Dinged due to terrible music, owner must have read that continuous high speed drums, etc. increase turns, somewhat insulting.  Otherwise great spot, great location.
author: Glenn S.

description: Our waiter was super friendly and helpful.  I like how they mix up their menu so everything is seasonal, fresh, and unexpected.  I loved the nettles ravioli and the egg/asparagus dish.  Good wine selection and cool atmosphere.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Very nice spot. Kinda reminds me of a Marina version of Coco500 (SoMa). The small plates here are Mediterranean and awesome, but very unique from what you'll find at other similarly styled restaurants. Portions are smallish so order 5-6 dishes for two. My favorite was the steamed mussels served in some sort of north African broth (best I've ever had - order extra bread to soak it all up). The wine list is great with lots to offer (both by the glass and bottle) from outside of CA. 

From the outside, the place looks like a regular house, but  inside, the decor is sleek and modern with great (low) lighting that makes everybody look good. Even though it's in the heart of the Marina, the place maintains it's sleek elegance late into a Friday evening when most similarly situated restaurants (even nice ones) turn into sloppy frat parties (which is OK sometimes, but not when you're out for dinner with the GF). Go there on a date, then get tanked at any number of bars nearby.

Service and staff are great - the place is owned by the same group that owns Rose Pistola (North Beach) and Rose's Cafe nearby.
author: Ez G.

description: Overpriced with some ridiculously small portions.  I get the tapas concept already but sharing ten strands of spaghetti? C'mon people (although I confess that I thought the spaghetti with clams was the best thing on the menu)!  Were it not for the mound of fries that we ordered at the end of our meal, my three friends and I would have left starving.  Oh, and our waiter was awkward and super-pretentious to boot (although hostess and bar folk were all cool).  I can only say I miss having Pane e Vino in this location. One star for delicious pasta (I can't give any credit for the good-tasting but mini prosciutto/melon appetizer cause I can make this rock at home).
author: Gelsomina L.

description: Went vegetarian here and was not disappointed at all.  In fact, it made the prices much more reasonable.  Ordered 6 dishes and all were amazing, I have a hard time believing that any items on the menu would not be great.
author: Zachary S.

description:
What a great find! From the outside you really don't expect to find such a large yet cozy space. It's the type of place you can roll in off the street after a long day or week. It would be great for a first date or an anniversary. I found it to be inviting and unpretentious. It is a little expensive but I expect that from a quality restaurant that uses fresh ingredients that makes their own mustard, desserts, pita bread, etc. Terzo also has the ambiance and service to back the price tag.

The food was incredible. The menu is designed to share, small and larger plates. The pita and hummus was the best I have ever had. Have you ever tasted fresh, made to order pita bread? Me neither, you will never want store bought again. The crispy soft shell crab resting on a bed of crisp green beans, tomatoes with a shallot vinaigrette was perfect and I was lucky to get the last one. The skirt steak was perfectly pink with the right amount of crispness on the outside and the flavor divine. For dessert we split the midnight cake, GOODNIGHT! It was perfectly moist a little dense and with a bite of the whipped cream I felt like I was eating the "Ritz Carlton" version of a ho ho!

Better yet was our service, Casey was helpful, knowledgeable, and absolutely charming. The type of person that you would want to pull up a chair and share a glass of wine.... and we did.

Terzo is a great neighborhood find and even if you are not in the hood I recommend making the trek from your neck of the woods to discover a great  all around dining experience.
author: kate n.

description:
Terzo is a fun space and very social, I ran into four people I know in the space of an hour.  The food is good but not great but it's a super social fun dpace to eat.  The wine list is very nice and very affordable given the level of restaurant.  

The sauces are meant to be sopped.  We loved the mussels and needed extra bread for it.  

A rruly social restaurant and meant for taking friends for a splurgy fun night out.
author: mary w.
